{"text": "I bought Factorio a very long time ago. Even back then it was a fresh and unique idea to build your own factory. The first few moments I've played I knew I will love this game. It's probably best described as kind of a puzzle adventure action strategy simulation. There is so much content, I'm sure it will take a many days of your precious life until you discover and build everything Factorio has to offer. The game is about managing your transport belts, so you can get everything where you want to have it. The game is about creating a network of materials and advanced products, e. g. the third generation of science packs is incredibly complicated if you don't have any clue about everything works as the game is also about the joy of figuring out how to accomplish certain things. I remember being very happy when I've finally figured out how to let drones place your solar panels automatically with a blueprint. Although admittedly the game can be a little scary at first considering the amount of content included, Factorio is ten (or even a hundred times) more satisfying and rewarding. There are no obvious bugs to be found since the devs put so much effort in bugfixing it's almost unbelievable. As far as I remember every major version has been being checked for even the tiniest and nastiest bug for weeks - or rather months. All machines, trains, resources, transport belts, trees - everything - look just beautiful. If you can't see the love put into this game here then you are probably a lost cause. lol Seriously, if you have a soft spot for either puzzlers, adventure, action, strategy or simulation games I can highly recommend this gem. You will get so much content for its money, Factorio certainly doesn't need to hide behind the one or other AAA game. Oh, did I mention it even has multiplayer? Also, make sure to read about the whole development process in the  . *** Review does not include recent changes! ***", "appid": "427520", "steamid": "profiles/76561198030098065", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "6", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1456401600.0}

{"text": "Absolutely love it, some great new features. Like with comfort food, you know what you're getting and you will never be disappointed.", "appid": "872790", "steamid": "profiles/76561198064036229", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1541160000.0}
{"text": "Well, first, stories about the dead coming back to life are a dime a dozen these days, mainly because of the current fascination with zombies and vampires, but rarely do we see a tale that's more akin to the legends of old, where mighty heroes brave the perils of the underworld to be reunited with their lost love. Sorry, that should be a 12 year old girl. Let's try this again ... So...first, stories about children having adventures in other worlds are a dime a dozen these days, but rarely do we see a tale that's more akin to the stories of old, where brave youths traversed other realms on a journey that would teach them ... lots of stuff. Nope, that's not going to work either. Let's try putting the two together ... Hoshi wo Ou Kodomo, which apparently means \"Children Who Chase Stars\" but for some reason is called \"Children Who Chase Lost Voices From Deep Below\", is the latest work from acclaimed creator and director Shinkai Makoto. The story centres on a small town in the countryside, where a young girl called Asuna spends her time after school listening to the strange music that comes from the crystal radio that her father left to her before he passed away. Everything is peaceful until one rather eventful day ... At it's core, Hoshi wo Ou Kodomo is an adventure covered in a philosophical blanket that doesn't quite fit, and it shows in many ways. The plot tries to blend a variety of themes, but it never really manages to do this with the panache of Shinkai's previous works. In addition to this, there's a childishness to the narrative that some viewers may find a little annoying, and quite often events are resolved in a manner that is very \"black and white\". Because of this the story lacks a good measure of catharsis, especially in comparison to \"5 cm Per Second\" and \"The Place Promised In Our Early Days\", and the film concludes with a rather lukewarm resolution. That said, the movie is interesting to a degree, but much of this comes from the way in which myths and legends regarding the underworld and resurrection are tied into the plot. Unfortunately, it's clear from the opening scenes that inspiration for the anime has come from a few very well known sources, and viewers may find that they spend more time playing spot-the-influence, and less time paying attention to the storyline. One of the first things that people will notice about Hoshi wo Ou Kodomo is the very \"Ghibli-esque\" atmosphere it has, but while this perception can initially be ascribed to the rural setting and the young lead character, the similarities actually run a lot deeper. The scenery is a rather pleasant blend of Shinkai's trademark panoramas and the kind of countryside imagery that one might find in \"Only Yesterday\" or \"Spirited Away\". Once the action moves beyond the gate, the background art and the settings dramatically improve, and the audience is treated to the kind of vistas that one would expect in a Shinkai feature. Unfortunately the same can't be said of the design, and viewers may be forgiven for thinking that the entirety of the movie is nothing more than an homage to a certain well known studio. The characters are so stereotypically Ghibli in fact, it's easy to imagine them searching for Laputa or farming in The Valley of the Wind. The similarities even extend to the animals, and while several of the more fantastic creatures wouldn't look out of place in the forests of \"Mononoke-Hime\", the strongest resemblance (in more ways than one), is between Asuna's cat Mimi and NausicaÃ¤'s pet Teto. Sadly, the comparison can only go so far as the characters lack visual refinement, which is further compounded by the lack of gradation in the colour palette used for them. When it comes to the animation, Hoshi wo Ou Kodomo is a long way from the best work produced by the long-running Shinkai/CoMix Wave Inc. collaboration. The action sequences are pretty decent for the most part, but the characters can sometimes move in a stunted manner, almost as if there's a degree of uncertainty about how each person should act or react in a given situation. In addition to this there are several scenes where the characters seem to have irregularly proportioned bodies, and viewers may find themselves wondering why particular events leave them with the nagging feeling that something isn't right. The theme song, \"Hello, Goodbye and Hello\" is a bittersweet ballad composed and performed by Anri Kumaki, and in all honesty it's a rather fitting song given the nature of the story. As for the background music, there's a rather nice mixture of placid or bittersweet orchestral tracks, light-hearted jingles and dramatic pieces, all produced by Tenmon - Shinkai's long-time compositional stalwart. Ironically, the movie excels when it comes to audio choreography, and with an array of high quality effects on offer it can sometimes feel as though more care has been given to making the feature sound good in a pretty setting, and not enough on developing the story. The script lacks a degree of intuitive flow, and the characters can sometimes state the obvious or wax philosophical for no reason other than to add a veneer of intelligence to proceedings. It's a sad fact that the dialogue can sometimes be stunted, and lacks the nuance that many viewers might expect. While some people may believe that this is due Asuna's age and lack of knowledge, the simple fact is that it highlights more than anything else how inexperienced Shinkai is with this type of movie. That said, the more than experienced cast have rallied well, but even with their ability to project emotion and personality, there are moments when they're unable to compensate for the heavy handed script. There's a strange dichotomy with the characters as on the one hand Asuna, Shun, Shin, and pretty much everyone else aren't really anything to write home about - especially if you've watched certain Ghibli movies. On the other hand Morisaki Ryuji is a very interesting person indeed, and is reminiscent in many ways of a more humane Ikari Gendou. Unfortunately he also suffers from the same problem in that he isn't given enough back-story to support his actions and decisions, but then, that's pretty much the tale of Hoshi wo Ou Kodomo in a nutshell. Although there is some development for the lead roles, it's often sporadic as the focus seems to be more on the journey itself. Shinkai Makoto has made it no secret that the inspiration for this movie came from a story he read in elementary school, but it was during his sojourn in England in 2008 that the idea for the anime finally coalesced into something more concrete. Which, strangely enough, explains rather a lot. There's a childishness to the movie that doesn't quite fit with the major themes of the plot, and in many ways it feels more like Shinkai was testing the waters and his determination, which isn't actually surprising when one considers that Hoshi wo Ou Kodomo is also his attempt to prove that he isn't a one-trick pony. While there are some positives that can be taken away from the feature, there are far too many things that have been \"borrowed\" from other films, and these make it difficult to see the movie as little more than an homage. In all honesty it would have been nice if Shinkai had the courage of his convictions and relied more on his own style (like he did with \"5 cm Per Second\" and \"The Place Promised In Our Early Days\"), instead of trying to piggyback on that of another studio. That said, Hoshi wo Ou Kodomo is a fairly easy movie to watch as long as the viewer doesn't delve too deeply, and it has a much lighter and more adventurous tone that Shinkai's previous offerings. In addition to this, if one considers it an experiment with a new type of story then it doesn't just become a reasonably entertaining feature, but also a glimpse into the mind of Makoto Shinkai, and that is a much more rewarding experience than the movie itself.", "appid": "518480", "steamid": "profiles/76561198281808088", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "18", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1499169600.0}

{"text": "Cortex Command is a strategy game with arcade elements. Our goal is to destroy the enemy base and defend ourselves. We have six factions to use, each with different units. To win we have to expand our base, extract resources and buy new combat units. Moreover, we can control the units we have created. For this we have prepared game scenarios, a map editor or access to the Steam workshop, from which we can download new campaigns or game beautification elements. It is worth noting the physics of the game. With time, the areas around us change, whether through our interference in the form of digging up raw materials or through explosions. Interestingly, the change of terrain stays with us until the end of the campaign. Unfortunately, the game has one big problem, and that is the difficulty of the game. This is the fact that as a new player it is difficult to understand what the game is about. The tutorial does not explain many issues, but even repulses. Moreover, the control in the game is hopeless and difficult to control. I will also pay attention to the graphics, which, as for 2012, looks weak. And although it is not an important part of the game, it may discourage new players. Cortex Command is an average game. Negative Bewertung nicht wegen den Verschiebungen, Server Problemen, Freeport gelagge usw., NEIN, ich dreh so langsam wegen der Ingame-Probleme durch.  1. Mindestens 50%, oder sogar bis zu 75% der Spielzeit wird gebraucht um nicht zu verhungen oder an Vitaminmangel zu sterben. Denn friert man, wird man so schnell hungrig, dass man sich eigentlich um nichts anderes mehr kÃ¼mmern kann. Oder wenn man halt nass oder es Nacht ist. Da hilft ein Lagerfeuer oder auch mal eine Fackel. Nur will man dann wieder mit Hilfe des Beils oder der Spitzhacke farmen, ist die Fackel nicht mehr in der Hand = frieren = Hunger!  Ich hoffe das das irgendwie noch angepasst wird. Auch berÃ¼cksichtige ich das es ja bisher nur Early Eccess ist, dennoch nervt es einfach sehr. 2. UND MEINE EIGENTLICH FRUSTATION: Wenn ich respawne ist mein Skillsystem stÃ¤ndig verbaggt. Ich kann plÃ¶tzlich nichts mehr bauen, obwohl alle Materialien vorhanden sind. Im Skill-Tree sind die zuvor erlenten Sachen auch wieder Schwarz. Das System funktioniert dann erst wieder beim nÃ¤chsten Level aufstieg. Die Skill-Punkte werden zum GlÃ¼ck nicht nochmal investiert, aber irgendwie kann ich die Sachen dann erst wieder bauen (werden dann wieder aktiviert), wenn ich in der jeweiligen Linie was neues erlerne. {"text": "If you are a fan of hardcore games with rogue-like mechanics then Necropolis is a game which you like. In this game death, which is permanent and you lose your progress, is a major part. To prevent that you have to increase your combat skills and your know how of the game. You will die and each play through you will learn something useful. There is no deeper story in that game, you play it because the gameplay. Necropolis is a third person action-role-playing video game. It takes places in a netherworld with moving platforms and hidden treasures. You can compare it to Dark Souls but much harder because if you die, it is permanent and after your respawn the levels are different every time. Death is by the way a major part of the game. It is the challenge not to die and that is hard. There are many traps and monsters with different abilities which want to kill you. So a main part of the gameplay is to increase your skills that you donâ€™t die. With the Unity Engine Necropolis has a very unique and minimalistic art style, like a cartoon, it reminds me of the graphics from The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker. Itâ€™s difficult to say that the graphics are good or bad but it is a fact that Necropolis has only little details. Positive with these art style is that the game is always clear with an awesome overview within fights. In addition to that you have a minimalistic but beautiful user interface, I like that. In conclusion I can only say that Necropolis has beautiful with a nice little UI, but you have to like that style. Jon Everist already composed the Music for Shadowrun which is a great soundtrack and also Necropolis has a very awesome music, it fits perfect and builds a diabolic atmosphere. Every run is different from the others because the levels are random generated. That also means that you can't really prepare yourself for the next time if you die. This feature makes the game a lot harder but I like that because every run is interesting and never become boring. You can play coop with up to four players which can be fun and easier but also annoying and harder than you expect because in coop friendly fire is always on. It's important to be careful where you strike your blade. Coop is a completely different experience than single player and that increase the fun of the game. Necropolis is a hard game and if you die, it is permanent. You can compare it with Dark Souls but it's very different. This game is much harder and does not forgive mistakes. Dark Souls is in comparison to Necropolis just an easy mode. If you don't like Dark Souls give Necropolis a chance, I hate it but I love Necropolis. Are you ready to die? I absolutely and wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone, and id happily pay twice the amount that i did for this game. {"text": "This game is amazing. I have completed every inch of the 1st playthrough, picked up every item available and beaten every boss and miniboss. Everything is perfect, the world and it's art design is amazing - the technicality of the graphics isn't top notch, but the design 100% makes up for this with some lovely particle effects from snowstorms, to drifting leaves to embers flicking around in the air. Every enemy and boss feels fair, if you learn the moves and how to appropriately handle them you will excel, but it requires patience and the right mind set - having played all from titles since DkS1, I was ready for this, but for a newcomer or more casual gamer this learning curve will come as a huge shock - if you can hang on it there and practise you will love this game. {"text": ".", "appid": "307690", "steamid": "profiles/76561198317875354", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1597838400.0}
{"text": "tl;dr: While it's an enriching tale I am glad to have experienced, only play this if you have plenty of patience, else it might be better to just watch a let's play instead. I am very torn about recommending this game. While frankly it feels like a glorified walking simulator padded with repetitive puzzles to extend the duration and generic combat that was added just to justify it being called a game, it's an experience that I never felt before and it's beautiful and emotive. This game tackles the rarely talked about subject of mental illness and psychosis in a way that hasn't been portrayed in most media, bringing it to the spotlight and being the core of the game mechanics. You get to see and experience the demons and twists in reality that are in Senuaâ€™s head in a unique and fascinating way, be it constant patterns she must find to progress, portals that alter the world so a previous blocked path is now free to traverse or broken shards of pathways that she can focus on and restore with her mind. The world is absolutely stunning and twisted and ranges from ruined villages and castles to the underworld with pools of blood filled with corpses or hands stretching out of walls to grab you. Senua often struggles with multiple voices who either help or hinder her in her journey, whispering insight and advice or demeaning and inspiring doubt. It's a delight to have them with you across the entire game, and the frequency and amount rises and lowers as the plot progresses. I rather not talk about the story since I feel itâ€™s best experienced blindly, but it's very well told in the confines of her perception and changes as she changes due to it, the ending initially seemed wanting but as I reflected more on it I understood why it was told this way. The combat is passable and revolves around basic and heavy attack, guard break, dodge and block/parry. While serviceable it feels somewhat basic and doesn't add much to the game. I became tired of it around midway, and while the game features three bosses only one felt interesting. Since there's no directional indicators you rely on the voices to know when an enemy will strike you from behind which I found to be a very nice touch. Exploring the world starts great and turns into a chore eventually, the locations are amazing and while there is some variation in a few puzzles, many revolve of the same mechanics and I wish were trimmed a bit to make the pacing more amenable. A few also overstayed its welcome like having to run in a labyrinth. While going forward in your quest you can find lorestones, collectibles that tell more of the story of the world and Norse mythology, they are really enjoyable to listen to but since I don't have patience for object finding I just watched the few I missed on youtube. Overall Hellblade is a better tale than a game, and you need to weigh if the pros outweigh the cons, it definitely did for me.", "appid": "414340", "steamid": "profiles/76561198015491592", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "42", "votes_funny": "3", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1593518400.0}

{"text": "I have a ton of time put into this game. It's very fun and very addictive. It's not the easiest game to get settled in, but once you do, it's a lot of fun. There's a lot of different countries to choose from. So, because of that, there's a lot of different vehicles to choose from. It's free-to-play. So obviously there's going to be a little bit of pay-to-win. But, once you get to about Tier 3 or 4, it becomes a lot of fun. Don't get me wrong, it's fun from the beginning. You just have to deal with people that are better than you because of what they're using. You'll deal with that throughout most of the time playing, but you'll have a lot better of a chance around Tier 3 or 4. But this game isn't comepletely pay-to-win. There's an app you can use to get Golden Eagles (the premium currency) for free if you don't want to spend any money, too. It'll take a while to get enough to buy anything of big value, but it'll save you money. So if you don't like needing to pay with real money to have an advantage, then you can work for it if you really want it. It's not a hard thing to do, it's just takes a little bit of time. So, back to the game. The game allows you to customize your vehicles a lot. You can make/download stuff to make the vehicle go from looking old and nasty to looking new and shiny, you can put decorations on said vehicle, you can even do both. You get to upgrade said vehicle as you play with it and then research more vehicles with the research points you get from playing. You can also upgrade your crews to be better at certain things, too. {"text": "A solid action-jRPG, but not without its weak points. While it shines in the combat department, offering a variety of different mechanics and interactions along with good progression and visualization of battles, it's just average/above average in almost everything else. The story is there, but there are plenty of cliches and you can see all the plot twists a mile away and if you don't they just stale and not exciting at all. The story also has a few really vanilla and unimaginative tear baits, which feel so tacky and forced that i can't imagine anyone would actually fall for them. As with the rest of \"Tales of\" series, graphics are just barely pass as current gen. and mostly because of good looking combat and somewhat good looking main characters - the environments are just incredibly dull and have a \"boxy\" feel to them. Also, as with previous games, Tales of Berseria has lots of unnecessary backtracking (although it's mostly optional). To summarize: Combat and character progression - great. Story - average. Graphics - below average. Design - average. Sound & Music - average. All in all, i consider the game worth the discounted price i payed for it during a sale, i have doubts about its value for a full price.", "appid": "429660", "steamid": "profiles/76561198021149544", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "7", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1499515200.0}

{"text": "The Convenience Store possesses a distinct low poly charm that is both nostalgic and creepy in its own right. It's this particular aesthetic, coupled with the atmosphere of the store which makes this little game a good one. Even if you only play it twice to collect both endings and spot anything that you may have missed the first time around. It sounds ridiculous, yes. Especially for a game as small as this. But scoff as you may, I did manage to miss a detail of note the first time around. The price is pretty modest considering what it does offer you in the fleeting span of time you actually spend playing it. It doesn't bog you down with a ton of needless errands or thumb twiddling, nor does it rush you in the front door, shovel tacky jump scares down your gullet and boot you out the back door again. You're given enough to immerse yourself into the role of working the graveyard shift, while the insidious nature of the store starts to unravel all around you. There are plenty of other little subtleties on tap here, but instead of highlighting them all for you I think it's best that you go discover and see them for yourself. The only real drawback for me was the story but even then; that's not really the centrepiece here. I would certainly hang out in this creepy little 24/7 convenience store after midnight again.", "appid": "1228520", "steamid": "profiles/76561198156418238", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "4", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1582804800.0}

{"text": "La verdad es que el juego lo compre gracias a la recomendacion de unos amigos,decir que lo compre cuando estaba de oferta a un euro,por si acaso no me gustaba,y he de decir que es el primer juego que tengo en steam que me he sacado todos los logros,y me he quedado con ganas de mas. basicamente el juego es un god of war con mala leche,,tiene sus defectos,como la poca variedad de enemigos,y es una pena que no este doblado,porque los dialogos es un humor absurdo muy bueno,pero corta la accion tener que estar leyendo a cada momento. {"text": "After playing this game for nearly 100 hours in total, I have to say it's a decent game for fun with your friends. It has it's downsides like all the hackers in the current stage of the game. But it's quite easy to come within the top 10 if you're decent at the game and within the top 5 if you are lucky, or just good. {"text": "Rust is a game that takes a lot to summarise with words. You start naked on a beach with a rock and a torch, starting into a world where literally everything you see will try to kill you. Players, animals, NPC's and even the damn catus try to take you out sometimes.   It's a game that lets you carry out your creative dreams while coming across both the highs and lows of society at the same time. Then combine it with hours of grinding and combat, fighting your way until you can hold a glistening new ak in your hands whilst standing atop your honeycombed 2x2. This might seem simple to those new to the game, but believe me when i say, making a play and reaching that level will always bring you satisfaction regardless of how many hours you have in the deadly world of rust.  Honest opinion, its hard to be a solo in rust. You find all these squads of geared players pounding up the food chain and leaving you in the dirt. But killing one of these squads and scurrying away to your 2x1 in the forest full of loot really does get your heart pounding like the drums of war.  As for squad game-play, you meet people in game and form alliances, You gather your friends and stomp a server, terrorising neighbours and battling the other clans spread across the map, and every time you win a fight, that friendship grows further. Rust is a game where i've built some amazing friendships, but also a game that taught me never to trust anyone unless they prove themselves to you, simple words like \"i'm friendly\" never sit right with me anymore.", "appid": "252490", "steamid": "profiles/76561198203370940", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "2", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1561896000.0}

{"text": "People are complaining a lot about this game because it doesn't live up to their expectations of the original, which is fair enough, but we are lucky to even get such high quality RE2 and RE3 remakes which didn't seem like a possibility a few years ago. Sure it doesn't have the wow factor of RE2R because we were introduced to a new engine, everything was shiny and fresh, this is just 'more of the same' and much like the original RE2 and RE3, the latter is more of an action-extension of RE2 where you revisit locations and characters.  The new Jill is fantastic and not some ugly feminist as some people seem to be describing. She's had the Lara treatment of being made believable to her environment, i.e, jeans instead of a skirt. I'm sure mods already exist to put her in lewd attire so this seems like a pointless argument again.  Her attitude and banter with Carlos is decent.  You might consider Nemesis to be less trilling than Mr X as he mostly chases you in small segments, scripted events and from point A to point B, but there are still a lot of tense moments with him and a variety of boss battles as he evolves. Visually the game is as stunning as ever, although it seems to lack some physics properties that were in RE2, zombies don't seem to flop around as much as they fall/die, I'm wondering if this is something in-engine that modders can turn back on. Perhaps it was toned down for performance reasons. The real negatives compared to RE2 are that it lacks a lengthy open-ended section like RPD. This is far more liner, you do have a few locations like the hospital that are slightly more branching but it's not half of what the RPD experience was. It does have some cool moments where it ties up things that happen in RE2, you see how certain things got to be how they are in RE2, I like how it links those aspects together. It might be pricey because it's probably 10 hours of content (including cut-scenes, reading notes and diaries etc) so if you can get it for 20-30% off then you've probably hit a decent value as it does include an online 4vs1 mode if you're into that and it will surely come with free DLC stories again in near future.  4 Jill Sandwiches / 5", "appid": "952060", "steamid": "profiles/76561197970575676", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "9", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1586001600.0}

The Community is really nice and loves to help new Players or Veterans. Ask whatever in the Chat and get an answer or more. For new Players it can be confusing what to do but with internal Help or external Help like the Wiki/Warframe Builder you should get your Info. The Game is good balanced for Solo to 4 Players play and frustrating moments are very rare. Warframe gets free Updates since first Days and these are sometime a big Content update. There you find the other sideâ€¦â€ â€“ Tormented Tree,  Developed and published by Angry Demon Studio,  , is a First-Person, Horror-Adventure title, steeped in Scandinavian folklore, unfolds the dark journey of Linn, the gameâ€™s protagonist.  Those familiar with this particular genre will know more or less what to expect.   doesnâ€™t go out of its way to surprise the player from a raw mechanics perspective. That said, the mechanics that are present are well designed and fittingly placed.  There is no combat system present. You are given no alternative but to operate on an avoidance basis when encountering foes within the game.  Some parts of the game are poorly illuminated by design but youâ€™ll be able to use matches to light your way forward. The matches donâ€™t burn for long and your supply is limited. This particular system I felt added to the sense of dread and urgency the game was trying to convey.  In order to progress at certain points, you are required to play one or more series of notes with the golden harp, provided around the gameâ€™s mid-way point. For those that may be hesitant at the difficulty of musical puzzles from other titles, all the notes and their sequence are provided for you in the game â€“ however, you may have to find the particular series of notes required for progression, as they are sometimes off the beaten path. While the inclusion of this particular mechanic is rather intrinsic, I think it couldâ€™ve added an added layer of complexity to make the game more difficult. â€œA chill down your spine, when you cross that thin line. Your mind might just break and shatter. Right is wrong, wrong is right but in that strange, twisted night who you are and were will not matter.â€ â€“    The game does present the player with difficult decisions in order to progress which was a nice touch. My only complaint if I were to make one was that I wish more of them were present and that alternate solutions existed for progression. That said, given the scope of the game, I understand why there werenâ€™t more. Itâ€™s an Unreal Engine 4 game done well. The graphics serve as an adequate vehicle for the story. Beyond that, the field of view is quite limited without any menu option for adjustment; however, I found it adequate for this particular title. Various graphical options are present including a crosshair toggle for screenshots.  The soundtrack is brilliant and the tracks are well placed. There was one scene that was particularly memorable, in which the innate terror of the scene and the soundtrack were harmonized exquisitely. The voice acting as a whole was done well. I particularly enjoyed the dialogue of the tree people placed throughout the various levels. Not only did they add some extra depth to the gameâ€™s lore but also a sense of dread and ambiance. I couldnâ€™t imagine playing the game without them.  The time to completion will vary but will invariably be quite short. Most initial playthroughs will likely be 3-4 hours long, possibly more if searching for all the journal pages without assistance from a guide.  The achievements are all in working order and will likely require at least an additional playthrough unless you specifically acquaint yourself with them and get them all done in your first run. Although, I do recommend against that as some of them do detract from the gameâ€™s enjoyment. You can reload any of the nine chapters from the main menu to specifically target certain achievements.    By the time I completed  , I felt I understood what was at the heart of the game. I think it was trying to address the nature of hell or rather our perception of it. The ending provided a rather metaphysical perspective that I felt was a nice touch.   tried to push the envelope in some sense, specifically with its inclusion of hard decisions. The game certainly did make me think at least once or twice in that regard. It also touches on the nature of hell and questions our perception it. Maybe hell can exist in a multitude of forms alongside each other. Maybe we each live our own form of it daily, without ever coming to terms with it. {"text": "It's difficult to categorize this game as \"strategy\" or \"tactical\" or anything else except maybe \"simulation\". It is quite unique. You're a disease and you have to destroy the human kind. As in \"kill all people on Earth\". That's at least what I say to people when I'm telling them about this great game I'm playing.  From the comments of the developer, he (or they?) actually do research on the various diseases and it shows in the game. From the basic mechanics of evolving the disease to the ways it spreads, it's hunted and cured and so on. Actually learned a lot from playing it that is directly transferable to the real world! (It's the other way around though ;) One of the best parts for me is the soothing music. It oddly fits perfectly with the otherwise grim scenario. Sometimes I casually play just to relax. That said, the game is easy to learn but difficult to master. Playing on Normal is quite satisfying but if you have or gained a deeper understanding of a specific disease you can play on the higher, very brutal difficulties. {"text": "As soon as I finished Rusty Lake: Roots I knew that I had to write a review for it to tell everyone how good it is. This is the first point-and-click adventure where almost every puzzle made sense, even when I got stuck, after checking hints/guides I was like \"ohh yeah that totally makes sense, how did I miss it\". {"text": "(Played during Free Weekend.) \"I already can play osu! mania, why should I suffer some more?\"  DJMAX is really fun. I haven't really noticed the input lag/latency issues yet. The online mode (ranked and lobbies) is pretty cool, although I don't really see a point to AIR lol. Guess it's nice to relax and listen to the game's soundtrack since it has auto-play. The Mission mode is also pretty neat, gives me an objective rather than grinding through the songs in Free Play. It's really nice to be able to change my key layout for every option, giving me the freedom to bind my controls to whatever I want. The song choice is wide, but the DLC is so darn expensive, I'm not sure if it's worth it. The complete edition without sale is $104, which I think is way too much for a rhythm game. Osu! mania has fanmade beatmaps, sure, but the whole thing is completely free. I'm not sure if I can justify spending $50, or even $37 (weekend deal sale), on this game. {"text": "Hey, that's pretty good :)", "appid": "379720", "steamid": "profiles/76561198066971327", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1479902400.0}
{"text": "Easily one of the best PC games released in the latest years. Easily one of the best surprises, too - you will see more passion and talent from those 'noobs' from Poland than you would in most of the AAA studios, combined. The sheer idea to be a rather indie studio and create a game like this, polish it (word origin nudges me weirdly here) and bring it to the extent it is available today, is remarkable and admiring. I have spent countless hours in the summer of 2011 playing and replaying the game. Because you don't get one strict and direct walkthrough; in fact, you can play 2 completely different storylines and make choices that will result in 16 (!) different endings. Mind you, I haven't seen them all (yet), but some craze at some point in the future might make me want to do so. Witcher 2 is an action-adventure RPG - you will see a lot of combat, and the combat mechanics will matter when you face tougher foes. You need a strategy to survive - button mashing won't help you. You can master either of the 3 skill paths - Magic, Alchemy and Swordmanship and use your signs, potions and gear in order to kick every monster and merc's a** in the beautiful world of Witcher 2. Speaking of beauty, as long as you have a powerful enough PC to push the game hard, you can't fail to notice how lovely it is made - the whole world looks like it is living and breathing, with NPCs having their own business throughout the day and sleep at night, lights, shadows and colours that make it all look hell pretty - the game might be 2011, but it still easily competes with some weaker attempts from more recent times. Everything in this game screams for maturity - from the portrayal of the storyline to some rather odd moments in the game - you might think nudity is not appropriate for games, but if you are old enough to think about it normally, you'll see there's nothing bad in a beautiful love scene like in any other movie. And indeed, the fantasy world of Witcher 2 is not a fantasy world meant for putting kids to sleep - it can easily be described as an alternative Middle Ages where humans have all their present strong and weak qualities, and the legends about the monsters lurking outside of the village at night turn out to actually be there for real. Comparing it to the first installment of the series, I would say I prefer Witcher 2 over it's predecessor, even though I wouldn't deny it either. Everything looks better thought of and finished in the follow-up, but the truth is, the Witcher 1 forged the path for the developers to get together and release a game like this. If you wonder, definitely play the first one first, but come back here when you've finished it. If you are at least a tiny little bit fan of books, don't think twice and grab yourself a copy of the Witcher stories- Andrzej Sapkowski is the mastermind of this world (book came first, then the game). Stories are not necessarily strictly connected between the books and the game, they are loosely situated in the same world, with the main protagonist being the white-haired cold-blooded and serious monster killer Geralt of Rivia. Who, by the way, is already one of my most favourite characters overall. In a few words - if you don't have the game yet and you are a fan of RPG, deep and mature stories and beautiful graphics: get it, get it now. P.S. Devs are real nowadays heroes as they release a ton of free downloadable content and updates AFTER the game is released. Yep, you get all those DLCs you pay for in the other games for free - and they added the Enhanced edition for free for all early purchasers too. They are also known for bashing the mandatory nowadays DRM too - if you buy the game retail, you just need the disc to play it. Like in the good old days. P.S. 2 I own the retail Collector's Edition of the game and I just had to buy it again on Steam. I don't mind it at all, I would put my money for those guys any day, as long as they keep releasing games like this (blink blink: Witcher 3; blink blink: Cyberpunk).", "appid": "20920", "steamid": "profiles/76561198029267869", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "164", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1392552000.0}

{"text": "while i recommend this game based on sayori's art, i can't quite recommend it based on gameplay. in-game purchases aside, the game is very simple and progresses like a clicker game without the clicking. treat this f2p game as a way of getting a CG-bundle from sayori for free over time and you won't be disappointed. if you came here for gameplay, please look elsewhere as you will be disappointed. to the developers: i hope you are planning to update and add more features and mechanics to this game. there is potential in it, especially considering the artist. the focus right now should be polishing the UI, adding some more customization (volume sliders, cutscene dialogue navigation, etc), and adding features/merchanics that are more engaging and reward player activity/planning similar to successful clicker games. 2018-05-22 edit: an update has added a clicking mechanic to the game. while you don't get a direct reward per click, your clicks charge a meter to activate a time-limited (<15s?) boost to income from all units. the boost has a 3 minute cool down so it forces you to take a break, which can be good for those who can get really into clicking. clicking on the wrong spot on a monster girl will lower the meter below a base amount which triggers a similarly negative effect on income. this negative effect has no timer and no cooldowns so be sure to keep the meter above the base amount. this is a step in the right direction. hoping to see more in the future. 2019-06-28 with only minor UI updates since my previous review and no updates in the past 6 months. this game is dead.", "appid": "533540", "steamid": "profiles/76561197965186524", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "4", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1526126400.0}

{"text": "The core elements of the Counter-Strike series havenâ€™t changed much since the original Half-Life mod emerged in 1999. That trend continues with the newest update, Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, for better and worse. Though the $15 downloadable title keeps the core of the seriesâ€™ gameplay alive, preserving the traditional maps, gun mechanics, and game modes, it lacks any innovation the FPS genre has introduced in the past decade and never introduces anything new of its own. The fact that Counter Strike: GO hasnâ€™t become just another â€œknock offâ€ of the Call of Duty franchise is reason enough for long time CS players to rejoice, but even they will be disappointed in the lack of fresh content. There are only a few new weapons. Plus, of the sixteen maps, half are recycled from previous installments in the franchise, including Dust, Dust 2, Office, Italy and Aztec. So, why migrate to CS:GO? For one, the visuals from Counter-Strike Source have gotten an upgrade, providing updated visuals to the old maps and more detailed weapon and character models. In addition to the Hostage Rescue and Bomb Defusal matches, CS:GO adds two new gameplay modes. Sort of. Arms Race is Gun Game with a new name. Thereâ€™s unlimited respawns and you receive a different weapon after each kill. This is a much faster-paced gameplay mode than the other modes, since it allows you to jump right back into the action after a death rather than having to wait for the next round to start. Itâ€™s a nice change of pace for CS:GO, especially if you are new to the series and havenâ€™t adjusted to its more conservative playstyle from modern shooters.  Domination is a mix of the Bomb Defusal and Arms Race modes. The terrorists can plant a bomb at the bomb site (to which the Counter-Terrorists have to disarm) or either side can eliminate all opposing players to win the match. There are no respawns in a match, so be prepared to spend a lot of time on the spectator screen if you run around with guns blazing. Domination isn't nearly the draw as the other modes are, as youâ€™ll more than likely stick to playing either Bomb Defusal or Arms Race. Itâ€™s even difficult to find any Domination matches that are fully populated. Those that loved the slow-paced, deliberate gameplay of Counter-Strike 1.6 or Source wonâ€™t be disappointed by any blasphemous changes to the formula. CS:GO keeps the core mechanics intact, but there are a few nit-picky changes that have been made. For instance, you can no longer screw a silencer onto the M4, and some of the old guns have been exchanged for more up-to-date versions (the MP5 is now the MP7). Also, some maps have had small paths added that open up congested choke points. While the lack of changes can be seen as a positive for long-time CS players, at the same time, it is also GOâ€™s greatest weakness.", "appid": "730", "steamid": "profiles/76561197963352493", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1467547200.0}

{"text": "In this expansion you play as \"Barney Calhoun\"; a mid-level security officer at the Black Mesa Research Facility who will became an actual standalone character with a great impact in the later Half-Life games, it's the day of the Black Mesa incident and your mission is to escape the alien invasion with the help of \"Dr. Rosenberg\" using some kind of old technology portal while fighting both aliens and army.  The story is really good and enjoyable with an awesome ending ( it's still cool even despite the fact that there is no final boss fight ), but sadly .. it's the shortest of the 4 expansions! the good thing is that it presents some new levels and areas of Black Mesa, yet no new weapons or enemies at all  i don't need to talk about the graphics & voice acting, the expansion was released 15 years ago and yet they still good for nowadays and they don't have any bad impact on the game-play.  Tbh, it was really nice to play as \"Calhoun\"and i loved how the story was mixed-in with the original story .. you can clearly see how many connections between them exists here.  Overall, if you loved the original half-life you should definitely try this one too! it's a great addition to the HL series and i recommend it to everyone, it doesn't matter if you are a huge fan or a newbie! just buy it now! {"text": "Fun game. Graphics look good. Career is just a bunch of races broken down into Categories. So stock car races and then like 12 to 13 events in that category. Their are a good variety of of categories. Like stock car, touring cars, ect. Graphics are sharp looking and the drivers are ok not as dumb as Project Cars 1. So that's a plus. I don't think hardly anyone races online. I checked and only found one race. You do have a teammate but he appears to be as dumb as a bag of rocks. Supposedly you can order him around but I haven't found a need for that yet. The tracks I have raced on all appear to be short tracks and not very many laps. That being said the tracks I have raced on did look very sharp. A carnival next to a race track and neon buildings right next to another track make the tracks pop. So the career mode has no story. Its just a series of races.   I got this game much much cheaper else where online. Fanatical is the web site where for 4 dollars you can get this game and Dirt 4 and some other game. A great value. I think for 10 bucks that might be a little on the high side considering I have seen this for much cheaper elsewhere. {"text": "I have not played long yet, and I will update this as I put more time into it.  First I love the idea described, but I don't feel it is delivered on correctly.  I was hoping to really have an opportunity to try to find my way to a destination with minimal information, but mostly they give you no chance to get lost, so I spent my time trying to find the least hazardous route.  I can say the camera is awful and they could stand to add more variety to the road conditions, it seems like they decided Russia is all made of mud.  And really I find it hard to imagine a game like this releasing with basically no support for steering wheels, though it is less needed in this game then racing games, but still I bought the stupid wheel because it's the only thing that make driving games less likely to make me want to throw my controller. So the fun parts, I really do think ultimately I like this game, but I do wish there was more of a \"game\" there, but maybe I just am not far enough yet.  I found the physics and the intense feeling as my big ugly truck hurtled down a hill I had no idea was there, to be pretty cool.  I think this game has a lot of potential and my hope is that they will continue to add content.  I don't like that this feels obviously like a game still in development, but was not indicated as such clearly, but that is the way of PC gaming now and I can't say there is any reason to wait any longer if you have been eyeing this, other then the price :)", "appid": "263280", "steamid": "profiles/76561198037324968", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "6", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1404388800.0}

{"text": "The base game is a little bit bare but it and the DLC are on sale more often than Valve games and Gmod so the value for money is still there. As many have described, this game is a little bit like Mario Party but without the minigames and that is a fair at-a-glance comparison, though 100% Orange Juice manages to give both more and less control to the players with regards to inter-player interactions and contests dependent on a random number generator, respectively. You see, while in Mario Party dice are used for movement and not much else, in 100% OJ the will of the die decides    . For this reason it takes a certain tenacity to put up with unfortunate series of events that would seem impossible at first but the game is happy to make all too real. Strongly recommended to play with friends, ideally a group of four* though if you enjoy the gameplay or want to grind out the unlockable content the game has to offer the online community is relatively welcoming and you shouldn't have trouble finding strangers to play with. *Every match will always have exactly four players, with bots filling in or excess players being restricted to spectating as appropriate. {"text": "This is only the demo for the final game, but I can say this is the first demo Ive ever played that actually sold me on the game it was promoting. Its an open world puzzle game set on a small island with 3 levels of difficulty that you must sequentially pass through to get to the final castle level. The mechanics were refreshing, the graphics were absolutely beautiful (with the most in-depth options menu Ive ever seen), and the game had me captivated from the start, between getting lore from both an in-game computer (that I hadnt fully explored) and a narrator I felt like my 30 minute escapade through the game fed me a teaser of a story that has extreme amounts of depth and envornmentally based story to delve into in the full release. In 30 minutes Ive turned around from not hearing a thing about this game to it being a definite purchase for me. ÐÑƒ Ð²Ð¾Ð¾Ð±Ñ‰ÐµÐ¼ Ð²Ð¾Ñ‚, Ñ‚Ð°ÐºÐ¾Ð¹ Ð²Ð¾Ñ‚ Ð¿Ð¾Ð»ÑƒÑ‡Ð¸Ð»ÑÑ Ð½ÐµÐ¾Ð¿Ñ‚Ð¸Ð¼Ð¸Ð·Ð¸Ñ€Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ð½Ð½Ñ‹Ð¹ Ð¼Ðº Ð´Ð»Ñ Ð¿Ðº, Ð½Ð°Ð´ÐµÑŽÑÑŒ, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ð¾ Ñ Ð¿Ð°Ñ‚Ñ‡Ð°Ð¼Ð¸ Ð¿Ð¾Ð´Ð¿Ñ€Ð°Ð²ÑÑ‚ Ð¾Ð¿Ñ‚Ð¸Ð¼Ð¸Ð·Ð°Ñ†Ð¸ÑŽ, Ð´Ð¾Ð±Ð°Ð²ÑÑ‚ Ð²Ð¾Ð·Ð¼Ð¾Ð¶Ð½Ð¾ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ð·Ð°Ð¿ÑƒÑÐºÐ° Ð½Ð° Ð½Ð¾ÑƒÑ‚Ð±ÑƒÐºÐ°Ñ… Ð¸ Ð¸Ð½Ñ‚ÐµÐ» Ð²Ð¸Ð´ÐµÐ¾ÐºÐ°Ñ€Ñ‚. {"text": "Tales of Berseria is one of my favourite games and a prime example of how story structure and character development should be. If you've played Tales of Zestiria, Berseria fixes a lot wrong with Zestiria's story and let's you understand the recurring characters and their backstories.    As I mentioned above, the story fills in a lot of gaps and does a better explanation of how the world works. Berseria takes place 1000 years before Zestiria does. The story kind of starts off a little slow, there is a known curse that happens, protagonist loses someone close they care about and that causes events to unfold. The story after that is mostly about the main character - Velvet - coming to terms with herself, getting her emotions back and caring about others again instead of being purely hate and rage filled on a blind suicide mission. Character development in this game is very strong and actually gets rather depressing at times, but it is done very well and has become one of my favourite games and stories. The game also takes a different spin as you're not playing as the hero, you're playing as the villains, who become the heros briefly due to a bigger threat, but in doing so, you singlehandedly keep the curse upon the world and further delve it into chaos. Everything that happens after this game (all the way to Zestiria) is simply because of Velvet and her party.  - Artorius starts out as someone just trying to keep his family and village safe from the Hellions, albeit through some rather extreme measures, who eventually turns into someone who wants to rid the world of emotion so no more Hellions can spawn and gets a god complex in thinking he's the only one that can be the people's hope and even attempts to control a god. - Velvet starts out as a laid back girl just looking out for her sick brother, after his death who she blames Artorius for, she becomes consumed by hate and revenge and will willingly sacrifice herself if it means Artorius's death. As time goes on she begins to get her emotions back and begins to care about others again, coming to terms with what happened and coming to terms with herself, while still keeping the goal she made. - Eizen starts as just the sarcastic know it all, who pretty much retains that, but also begins showing more character as someone that wants to protect and help others. He's looking for his pirate crew's captain even after suspicion of his death, just so there is closure. Mentions multiple times he's trying to stay away from his sister because he knows he'll turn into a dragon and will cause harm to her, which he goes out of his way to enlist help from others to keep her safe and even helps another character, Zaveid come to terms with his denial over a loved one. - Zavied starts as a very cocky and plays a lot with the more carefree personality and not taking much serious. Zavied is very against killing, which eventually comes to light because his lover had turned into a dragon from malevolence corruption and he's in denial that she can't be reverted, thinking that everyone can be saved. Eizen is the one that shows him this is false and he needs to accept the fact that sometimes saving someone is killing them. They fight against Zavied's lover and Zavied comes to her defense multiple times, where he finally sees that she's gone and never coming back. Eizen has the chance to kill her and take her heart to reverse his own curse, but instead doesn't, in order to set her free in death, which Zavied makes a promise that he'll return the favour once Eizen turns and that he'll protect Eizen's sister. This is extreme foreshadowing and actually changes Zavied's outlook in Zestiria.  There is much more character development from others, but I don't want to spoil everything.   The graphics for the most part are pretty good. There is some slight AA issues on higher resolutions sometimes and some background environments may look a little plain, but the effects of moves, cutscenes be it the animated style or the actual game cutscenes are very nice. There are some gorgeous overworld areas as well with enough life given to them, just some dungeons and caves look a little too plain.   This is one where I'll say Zestiria beats out Berseria. Berseria by no means has a bad soundtrack, it has a great soundtrack, but it didn't match the feel I got from Zestiria's OST. With that said, music for Berseria that is done by the Tales of Orchestra is very strong and eclipses past Zestiria in my opinion.   Gameplay is very fast paced in combat, which I like. The fast paced, combo/button spam free fight fits this game's narrative and pacing way better than turn based. Movement within the overworld is a little slow at first, but as you beat bosses and mini bosses, you'll get passive items that increase your speed. You'll be reading a lot of dialouge at times, through skits, chatter whilst moving around and cutscenes, which may get annoying for some, but something I personally didn't mind. Grinding levels in this game isn't that bad, most characters have some sort of \"spammy\" attack that should get you through if you pay attention to enemy weaknesses. Post game is an okay size, you have the Zavied and Dragon arch, an EX Dungeon and I think a few little side quests here and there. There isn't really much I can think of, as they're really going to be based on a person's preference. I'll name a few and the bolded one is an actual con.  - Combos are very easy and honestly, there is plenty of moves that you can just spam over and over again no problem to just speed through enemies.  - Long story that some might be turned away from. You will probably sink about 40 hours into the main game and maybe close to 60 if you do post game. This is \"exacerbated\" by a lot of dialog and skits that pop up.      - Fantastic story that that has amazing character development and gets depressing by putting moral questions within yourself trying to determine if Artorius is correct or if Velvet is correct. - Sound track that for the most part is very good and has plenty of memorable scores, but does fall a little short to Zestiria. - Fast combat gameplay that fits the pace of the game and keeps things moving. - Plenty of dialog if you're interested learning about the characters and the world. - A very good amount of gameplay to be had through enemies, exploration, bosses and post game.  -      Tales of Berseria is seriously a game people need to try out. I won't make the argument that it's the best Tales game, as others have their own preferences, but it's my favourite Tales and one of my favourite games in general. The story is the main driving force for this game and everything else with it is just an added bonus to me. Legit, they could have turned this into an anime or even a movie and I would have been more than happy, but getting to play alongside it was fantastic. As I mentioned at the top, if you played Zestiria and was underwhelmed or felt like it was an uphill battle or had too many inconsistencies and/or poor explication, give Berseria a try. It seriously fixes so much that Zestiria did wrong and really puts the story for this universe together. It also sets up the plot for a third story, which I hope they go back to explore eventually since Tales of Arise is confirmed not to be apart of this universe. If this is your first Tales game or consideration, I can not recommend this game more than I already have. 10/10 game!", "appid": "429660", "steamid": "profiles/76561198119227091", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": "38", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1565784000.0}

{"text": "As in previous Fallout DLC tradition a new quest and radio station will appear on your trusty pip-boy device. Choosing to follow the pointer on your map will take you to a long abandoned Brotherhood of Steel bunker that is accessed by a grate in the sand. Of course your human curiosity means that you are going to enter the bunker and when you do you will be subjected to a some kind of sleeping gas that knocks you out cold in mere seconds. When you come round you will find that you've been whisked away to the isolated resort talked about in folktales 'The Sierra Madre casino'. History explains that 'The Sierra Madre' never opened due to some nuclear bombs exploding, which has left the resort trapped in a toxic cloud of red and presumably smelly fog stuff. Legend also tells of a casino vault that remains untouched and that many greedy adventurors have tried, but failed to claim it's riches. Getting into the casino as you've guessed was never going to be as easy as strolling up to the front door and pressing the door bell. Especially if the Ghost People have anything to do with it. They are tough and come armed with some not seen before weapons like big pointy spears and boxing gloves made with bear traps. Not being very friendly at all, they'd like nothing more than to poke you or thump you, they really are not fussy which it is. Enter Father Elijah and his dastardly plan to gain access to the casino and it's lost treasure. I should mention that said dastardly plan involves little old you and an exploding collar to ensure obidence to your new master at all times. Elijah has also removed your Mojave loot, your armour and all of your previously acquired weapons. Your companions have also returned to their homes too. Your first task is to make some new friends. More specificaly friends that have been hand picked by Father Elijah himself, who like you are also wearing an explosive collar to keep them in line. Dean Domino is a confident playboy type. He is debonair and also a Ghoul who before the war was a very popular entertainer. Dog or should I say God perhaps, is a Super Mutant with a split personality. He changes from the pleasant and educated God to the blood thirsty Dog. Finally there is Christine, a mute woman who easily has the most interesting back story of the bunch. The explosive collar clamped around your neck has a nod towards the movie world and is on the surface quite an interesting idea. You quickly find that your collar can suffer interference from radio signals and the speaker systems that are dotted around the resort. The bleeping sound that the collar emits raises the tension and requires that you search for the source of the interference before you lose your head. Some of the radios can simply be switched off by interacting with them and some of the speakers can be shot to silence them. But there are those that are protected and can only be dealt with by hacking the associated terminal. Taking part in the local economy will require the use of casino chips as bottle caps have no value at 'The Sierra Madre'. Traders and caravans are nowhere to be found, only abandoned vending machines designed for use by the resorts visitors offer any kind of retail therapy and they can also be used to purchase some sustenance should you be feeling in need of a little pick me up. However finding just one of your five a day is probably going to prove difficult. Much better items can be purchased later on and it is also possible to trade in items you have looted such as clothing, weapons and cigarettes for chips. The holographic security system inside the casino adds an element of stealth to proceedings. The security drones have a limited range due to their emitters but be warned they are completely indestructible and are heavily armed with lasers. Dealing with their programmed routine via a terminal is a sensible course of action. Be prepared to run for your life though if you are spotted. There is a sizable amount of story to digest here and a huge helping of back-story that unravels some of the mystery surrounding your bunch of new found friends and the tainted history of the resort that never opened. Experiencing all that Dead Money has to offer will easily consume 8 hours and more if you attempt to find every detail. You will need to ensure that you've checked under the bed and down the back of the sofa because after you have left the Sierra Madre there is unfortunately no return ticket. I think it's fair to say that DLC for the popular Fallout 3 game have been on the whole successfully integrated into the game world and story. Fitting DLC into an RPG is certainly no easy task and requires a lot more thought that just a new map layout or some new weapons and armour. DLC for an RPG needs to slot in with the overall narrative of the game and integrate fully with the characters and the world that they inhabit. Dead Money continues this success and never feels seperate from the Fallout world.", "appid": "72730", "steamid": "profiles/76561197972374059", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "7", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1576497600.0}

Las cutscenes se ven muy bien. Me trae buenos recuerdos de cuando lo juegue por primera ves con una PC que apenas cumplia los requisitos minimos (Pentium III 800Mhz, 1Gb RAM, Geforce 2 MX) y de todas formas lo termine (hay una parte que fue un terrible dolor de bolas). {"text": "Saquen el Future, PLS!!", "appid": "205950", "steamid": "profiles/76561198199364833", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1605873600.0}
{"text": "One of the single best F2P games I've ever run across. You do yourself a disservice if you don't give it a try.  Description ------------ Basically it's a Co-Op style FPS where you run instanced missions with up to 3 other teammates. You have the option of using many different Warframes (or 'Classes') A primary weapon, a Secondary weapon, a melee weapon and a companion (who can also potentially bring a weapon).  The game has a very fluid movement system meaning that with practice you can traverse the maps within seconds. I truly haven't had this much fun with the movement in an FPS since Tribes (and Tribes 2). Couple that with an enormous array of weapons and abilities you can use in this game and you have something you can spend thousands of hours playing.  You do need to pick up components and blueprints (although many blueprints can be bought) to build these weapons/warframes etc. but since the gameplay is actually enjoyable it doesn't feel too grindy.  It also uses a card-style system of mods that change the aspects of the weapons and Warframes which allow you to customise your equipment to your liking. This essentially equates to a ridiculous number of combinations of mods and equipment to try out. The matchmaking is top notch, meaning that you can select public and just jump into a mission and have up to 3 other people join you. You can of course limit this to friends or clan-mates or even tackle the missions solo if you want to. After the mission is over you can just go your separate ways or if you want vote on a new mission and see if they want to join you. It's so easy that any apprehension about playing with others is quickly forgotten as you progress through the solar system opening locations to run missions.  There is also a nice storyline and several quests that push the story forward, unlocking more features as you progress in the game. The latest large update brought a massive outdoor location on earth, and while it is still instanced in a way it's very different from the normal missions.  The game runs remarkably well and looks great, keeping a nice smooth framerate as you jump, glide, slide and shoot your way through the maps. Honestly I've never played a game quite like Warframe, and I highly recommend checking it out for yourself. Just make sure you change the graphics to windowed or windowed full screen. There is a strange issue with full screen that makes your mouse lag. TLDR; F2P done right, Go play this Co-op FPS and enjoy yourself.", "appid": "230410", "steamid": "profiles/76561197971074265", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1516968000.0}

{"text": "This game is an absolute classic, aged like a fine wine. You play an unfortunate hero (simply known as XIII) who had lost his memories and was hunted by a group of secretive people who use numbers as a cover for their names. You set off to uncover the story behind it all while staying alive. The missions are really fun, various weapons and equipments are at your disposal. Just to mention a few examples, depending on the locations, you can take hostage to prevent enemies from shooting at you, use grapling hook to climb, shoot enemies underwater using harpoons and destroy helicopter with bazooka. Certain missions require stealth approach, where you need to hide bodies to prevent enemies from discovering you. Objects such as chair can be used as melee weapon to knock enemies unconscious. The story is told in comic book fashion, and the game graphics are also in the same way. This has some an interesting effect, such as killing an enemy with a headshot will display a cartoon showing the enemy falling to his death with words bubble around him.  The campaign is roughly 8 hours during my playthrough,   Also, do remember to save regularly, because the game doesn't have autosave. You can only respawn at checkpoints if you die at anytime. Otherwise, you will lose all progress when you restart the game. I have not tried the multiplayer mode to comment on that. A remake of XIII will be released soon, but in the mean time, this game will surely satiate the craving for that.", "appid": "1170760", "steamid": "profiles/76561198025858988", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "2", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1604491200.0}

{"text": "Ð½Ðµ Ð¸Ð´ÐµÑ‚ Ð¿Ð¸ÑˆÐµÑ‚ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾Ð²ÐµÑ€ÐºÐ° Ð²ÐµÑ€ÑÐ¸Ð¸ Ð¸ Ð²Ð¸ÑÐ¸Ñ‚", "appid": "374670", "steamid": "profiles/76561198137533460", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1566302400.0}
{"text": "The Yakuza series has piqued my interest for a long time now. Whether it be through fun memes depicting the ridiculous side content the series has established as a selling point or recommendations to play the game from reviewers. Yet I've never got to give the game a chance myself. That is, until now. Set in 80's Japan, Yakuza 0 follows Kazuma Kiryu and Goro Majima, both of which are related to the infamous crime organization, the yakuza.  Kiryu's story starts in the fictional district of Kamurucho. Tasked with collecting a debt from an uneasy civilian, we get off to a swift beginning with the opening scene showing him beating up the civilian relentlessly. This ordinary yakuza errand run ends up being the beginning of a larger scheme, as Kiryu discovers the unfortunate reality that someone has framed him. The news media are quick to catch on: a man has reportedly been found dead in an empty lot in Kamurucho after he was severely beaten and finished off by gun. Now Kiryu must prove his innocence before it's too late. Meanwhile, in the district of Sotenbori, located in Osaka, Goro Majima manages the prominent cabaret The Grand. However, this luxurious living serves only as a way to conceal his past. Three years before the events of Yakuza 0, Goro disobeyed the orders of a higher-up, which had adverse consequences for the young Majima. However, one day, he receives an offer. If he can kill a person of interest, he can return to the life he was declined. But does he have what it takes to seize another human being's life?  Both stories are compelling and will undoubtedly hold your attention for the entirety of its runtime. You switch between the two protagonists every second chapter, resulting in constant excitement for what comes next for both Kiryu and Goro. There's not a lot of unnecessary story padding either. Save for some dialogue scenes being too long for their own good the pacing is on point.  Voice acting in Japanese games are often a mixed bag. Luckily, Yakuza 0 makes an exception. You don't have to prepare yourself for cheesy and monotone deliveries of lines. The game is only available with Japanese audio. It might be a bummer for some, but I found it to add to the authenticity and immersion. Yes, you will have to read subtitles, but is that a big deal? When you're not delving into the crime thriller that is the main story, what you'll spend most of your time doing is engaging in the array of minigames. As soon as you get through the first chapter and unlock the ability to walk around freely, it's likely you'll spend the next few hours hitting up disco clubs, playing darts, and singing karaoke.   It's quite impressive how much stuff they managed to cramp into this game. From Texas Hold 'Em and Blackjack to disco and karaoke, there's a lot to engage with as a player. They even managed to integrate a few old arcade games, such as Space Harrier, into the game. I can only imagine how much of a challenge that must have been, considering the probably dated coding of these titles compared to the complexity of modern game engines.  Better yet, these games feel like the full experience, not just a simplified one. Sadly, the game doesn't do a fantastic job of introducing you to the intricate systems some side activities offer. Shogi, a game that I had never played before, is a good example. The game just threw the basics of the game at me, instead of explaining it as I got along. Then there's Mahjong, which requires you to memorize not-so-distinct kanji symbols.  The game also introduces you to a range of substories, this game's side quests. There's a dazzling one hundred to find. Imagine purchasing this game expecting to spend the next 30 hours enjoying a thoughtful story about the consequences of getting in touch with the criminal underworld, only to suddenly encounter a half-naked man taking to the streets to look for girls. That's Yakuza 0 for you. I spend more time than I anticipated acting like a girl's boyfriend to impress her father, teaching a fake punk band the ins and outs of the culture, and battling a man with a life-long aspiration of becoming the strongest creature alive. Survival of the fittest, I guess. It's quite a contrast from the tales of Kiryu and Majima. It might sound like this is shaping up to be one of the game's weak points, but that's not the case. The Yakuza games are famous for their contradictory themes, and 0 does it so well that it only feels natural.   There are also examples of serious storytelling here. My favorite substory was about a family father who had a secret past with the yakuza. Even after he left behind his criminal life, they continuously hunted him down. His only escape was to get plastic surgery as well as a change of identity. While he managed to lay low, it came at the cost of losing all contact with his family.  Where the substories fall short is in their presentation. None of them have any voice acting, resulting in a seemingly lifeless experience. It seems like a weird budget choice, as the game so heavily relies on its side content. The music used for them is repetitive, with the same beats looping over and over. It doesn't help that there's only about three of them.  At the heart of the gameplay is the combat. It's a classic Beat 'em up in which you plow through enemies with style. It's more grounded than most in its genre, but that doesn't imply it isn't over the top. You'll be stomping on people's faces, or smashing them with a bicycle. It's flashy as heck, and I love it! The moves are fun to execute and often followed with a satisfying, cartoonish crunch sound effect. The combat soundtracks are great, with instruments kicking in at just the right time.  Both protagonists have three combat styles at their hands. Sadly, Kiryu's styles are less intriguing than Majima's, as they focus solely on the basic mechanics of the game. Those of the latter focuses more on the sheer fun of combat, with one style offering everything that all of Kiryu's does. You can acquire various upgrades as well as new moves by \"investing in yourself\" with the money you've acquired.  Yakuza 0 looks like something that released during the previous console generation. When you explore the streets of Tokyo at night, everything looks fine and dandy. But when the sun rises, that's when the game's secrets become more apparent. Low-resolution textures are everywhere, and the interiors of buildings often lack detail. The only exception is the character models. The level design suffers too. The areas you're allowed to explore are gated off by invisible walls, something which I thought the games industry had long ago dished. The smaller areas of the game have arcadey level design.  In short, Yakuza 0 was everything I hoped for; a compelling crime thriller combined with a plethora of side content. Although slow-paced, its story ultimately pays off in the end. Unfortunately, some aspects of the game feel dated, especially the graphics looking like something from the previous generation of consoles.  ã€€ðŸ‘ã€€Surprisingly gripping story with phenomenal writing and voice acting ã€€ðŸ‘ã€€Will keep you busy for a long time with all its side content ã€€ðŸ‘ã€€Flashy combat with moves that are fun to execute ã€€ðŸ‘Žã€€Some aspects feel dated, especially the graphics and level design", "appid": "638970", "steamid": "profiles/76561198298903892", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "144", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1595246400.0}

{"text": "Ð¡ÑŽÐ¶ÐµÑ‚ ÑÑ‚Ð¾ Ð³Ð»Ð°Ð²Ð½Ð¾Ðµ, Ð° Ð² Mafia II ÑÑŽÐ¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚ Ð½Ðµ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾ÑÑ‚Ñ‹Ðµ Ð½Ð°Ð±Ñ€Ð¾ÑÐºÐ¸. {"text": "...", "appid": "444200", "steamid": "profiles/76561198309352804", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1496232000.0}
{"text": "This is my kind of game; a tactical fantasy game with some rpg elements.  Sin Slayers sees you take on the 7 Deadly Sins that are corrupting the world, without succumbing to them yourself. Trying to take on the evil taint of Gluttony without empowering them on the way - if you're low on health and eat food? You're only giving Gluttony strength! You'll also discover random events on the map level, where your decisions will either increase the power of the enemies, or decrease it, depending on your actions.  You begin the adventure with the holy trinity of heroes - Tank, Healer & DPS. Shortly after you discover The Protector that adds more Tankage. Don't worry though, each hero has a talent tree that allows you to respec them slightly, changing abilities or passives, to help the team out. Combat is turn based and reminds me of classic Might & Magic in some regards, but is clearly its own thing, which works surprisingly well. The more you fight a similar type of enemy, the more you discover about them - such as their strengths and weaknesses - and you'll quickly build up a profile and strategy to defeat regular occurring mobs. It would have been nice to see the tactical element expand in to the combat with movements, flanking, and combinations similar to something like Disgaea or Tales from Candlekeep: Tomb of Annihilation. However, what is presented works well and has enough depth to remain interesting and challenging.  The writing and voice over work is the only detraction from what is a good game. The dialogue is simple, and the voice over sounds stiffed and sometimes doesn't match the subtitles/in-game text.  Even with that in mind what you're going to get from Sin Slayers is a fun adventure game that you can play at your own pace thanks to the turn-based combat. You can read more reviews here:", "appid": "783190", "steamid": "profiles/76561197966244188", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "14", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1567684800.0}
