{"text": "Metro Last Light is a linear story driven horror survival FPS with multiple endings, It has great graphics and some very tense gameplay, Customize your weapons and save the Metro from itself. The Story follows the adventures of Metro 2033, It is also based on a novel with the same name, People are still in the metro because of the invisible threat above ground. You play as the same protagonist from 2033, Artyom, Not much has changed, except for the shift of focus of enemies. I feel the mutants are less considered threats here, Surely you still need to kill them if they attack you, But in the last game they felt like the enemy, And here I feel other humans are the real enemy. The game like 2033 has multiple endings, So maybe that was just the impression the game gave me by the choices I made. In the last game I did not feel any of the characters stood out or where particularly memorable but I do feel they improved on the NPC characters this time, there was more bonding and faces started to get familiar. Saying I care about their wellbeing is a bit over an overstatement, But it surely improved a lot and I was curious towards them to say the least. The rest of the game felt really similar to the last installment, But that is not a bad thing.  There is no multiplayer at all, It is all single player, Mainly the story mode, There are some extra missions which are pretty cool, Chapter select is still there But you can not go back trough normal progress, It is a very linear game, You are rewarded for exploring but any door could close shut behind you. Your choices do matter and in my experience it is rather hard getting the good ending. Like the previous game you can choose between Survival or Spartan for your run, Spartan is more head on with easier enemies and more ammo while Survival is a more sneaky way of playing where it is better to evade enemies. Then there is Ranger mode which makes the game a lot more realistic in terms of difficulity, 2 bullets will be the end, But enemies go down a lot easier too, If you really want a Survival experience I would recommend going with that. I played the game on Survival, But I went trough it as a Spartan, and I had tons of ammo to spare mostly.  The main story is a  shooter with a very tense Horror like atmosphere, There are some parts you have to follow people around or stuff like that, but it did not feel like a chore at any point. There are also a lot of different \"New Missions\" these are like extra missions you can play and some are pretty cool, There are sniper missions but also wave missions, all kinds of cool stuff that you will enjoy if you like FPS games. Like Metro 2033 The game looks beautiful, surely it is all Dark and Grimey, But it creates an incredibly tense atmosphere, The sounds really enhance this feeling. The pre rendered movies look horrible, They have very bad graphics and play in 30fps. It is like it was pre rendered using a microwave. Next to that everything looks great, especially considering the age of the game. I also love the design for some of the weapons, Like the Shotgun Revolver, Who thinks of insane weapons like that. The game runs really well, absolutely no crashes, glitches or bad behavior like that. Like Metro 2033 It does have some issues with Vsync, It works, but not always, Other times you can't turn it off, It is a bit strange, But it is not a huge issue, It also has bad mapping with the default kernel driver using an Xbox One controller, It works fine with Xpadneo, so if you play with a controller, use xpadneo. I am a little dissapointed with the endgame, Like Metro 2033, The game is extremely linear, It is very easy to miss things. There is a chapter select, But it will overwrite your last savegame and you can not go back and clean up the achievements. The replayability is okay, Since it has multiple endings and multiple ways to play. There are also a lot of achievements that are easily missable, If you want to perfect the game it will certainly take you a while. Overall, The game is very similar to Metro 2033, At least I see very few differences between the 2 Redux versions, So this review might sound very similar to the review of 2033. Just like that game it surely is a great game worth picking up, And a must have if you like anything related to FPS or Horror. It is a short but thrilling ride a very linear ride but how you ride it is completely up to you, Kill or Sneak. Good or Bad.", "appid": "287390", "steamid": "profiles/76561198087610673", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "80", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1592481600.0}

{"text": "I can't believe that this game is getting scores like 30%. It's an 'on-the-rails' shooter, like Time Crisis and the age-old 'Operation wolf' (remember that), and doesn't pretend to be more. The graphics are nice, not mind-blowing but very decent, and the game has a silky smooth framerate. If you're expecting an openworld FPS then you're going to be disappointed, but if, like me, you are a fan of those ever-diminishing light-gun games, this is a worthy addition. My only real complaint is that it would clearly be better suited to using a light gun, and the pc version doesn't appear to have that option. Other than that it's good fun, and a good way of getting in some target-practice in preperation for any other FPS multiplayer games. Just know that you are buying a no-brainer rollercoaster of a game, not a shooter which requires to much of the old grey matter. It's just a bit of arcade-shooter fun! 75%", "appid": "274130", "steamid": "profiles/76561197998664725", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "39", "votes_funny": "3", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1392984000.0}

{"text": "With the many platformers and puzzle games constantly being released, The Bridge changes up the puzzle genre with an extremely unique take on puzzles. This game forces the player to view the game in different ways. The mind-bending puzzles has the player's reevaluate the preconceptions they've had on physics and perspective of the world. \"It is Isaac Newton meets M.C. Escher.\" The puzzles consist of one or many intricate architectures where the player has to manipulate gravity to complete the levels. The levels of the puzzles gradually increase, leaving a sense of accomplishment after completing them. The beginning puzzles start out extremely easy, letting the player finish in a minute or two, but the puzzles towards the end can leave a player stump for days unless they look up a guide or have someone else look at the puzzle (a different set of eyes can look at the puzzle at a different angle). Not only is The Bridge a highly intellectual game, the artwork is something to behold. Many art enthusiasts would enjoy the game, simply for the art. The art style is hand drawn black-and-white lithograph. At first glance, the art did not appeal to me, but after completing the game 100%, I saw how beautiful something so simple can be. With all that said, I dare you, reader, to complete this game 100%. The puzzles can leave you weary and your brain hurting, but the sense of accomplishment is well worth it.", "appid": "204240", "steamid": "profiles/76561198041960474", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "70", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1373889600.0}

{"text": "This is a basic typing tower defense, but if you can't type at least 30 words per minute, then it may be a little too fast-paced for you. Also, if you can get past the congestion of enemies within the first 20 waves, then the rest is smooth sailing. The main problem with this game is stages 15-25. There isn't much of a gap between waves and you'll still have half of the wave to go through when it spawns another. The best way to avoid running into this problem is to just save up all gold and don't buy anything until you have 300+the upgrade cost. This allows you to upgrade and still have enough to continue if you mess up. It costs 300 gold to continue, and it also launches a bomb attack which recuperates about half or more of the gold you spent on the continue in the early stages. It would fully recuperate your gold and maybe give you more in the later levels due to the increased gold gain. This game isn't bad, but the small timer in-between the early games can be extremely frustrating. This game is great for easy achievements and a hour of monotony, but if you're looking for a more interesting and casual typing game, then I'd pick up Epistory instead. It's a fun game with beautiful graphics and a customizable difficulty that can also adapt to your skills.", "appid": "904440", "steamid": "profiles/76561198067585596", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1584360000.0}

{"text": "Get yer stealth-murder on. MARK OF THE NINJA is a 2D side-scroller stealth game, with gobs of replayability. Premise:  you're a ninja.  Specifically, a ninja with magical insanity-inducing tattoos.  You sneak through levels on behalf of your clan, dispatching enemies quietly- or noisily - or just letting them live.  Up to you, really. The real fun of this game is how many different ways you can play it.  With each level, you can equip different tools (for attack or distraction), and a different costume.  The costumes and equipment unlock as you progress.  Each costume and item has strengths and weaknesses, and each will change how you play.  The Nightmare mask, for example (my current favorite) is built on terrorizing your enemies into murdering each other. Heh heh heh. If that's not your cuppa tea, that's okay.  There are six (seven, if you got the DLC) costumes to choose from. The achievements are very well done - they're challenging, but not impossible.  Two playthroughs can get you all of them, though you may be tempted to keep going even after getting 100% Highly recommended.", "appid": "214560", "steamid": "profiles/76561197987532511", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "4", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1434283200.0}

{"text": "Resist or Embrace I completed Sundered and had a great time. You guide the woman Eshe into a forgotten ruins of the science minded Valkyries and the occultist Aschaton. The non-linearity as I unlocked all the abilities before I even found my first boss (I had just missed a door but cool to have all the toys if you want), beautiful art and sound design, moody music, intriguing setting, the escalating hordes basically demanding you either fight or run, death woven in as more of a break rather than a punishment--though I have died right before unlocking shortcuts. Still it's strangely relaxing. The roguelite elements will vary sections of the game while key locations will remain constant. The variation made it so I couldn't just sleep walk to bosses but furiously check my map, sometimes while on the run. There are a variety of skills to unlocks and use which can further be improved by Resisting and burning Eldar Shards, or Embracing and using them to corrupt those abilities for Eldritch powers. I went full Embrace on my first run and this led to some definite improvements that did in fact make the game easier. Suffice to say these choices also play into the ending you get. I will definitely do another playthrough to see Resist at some point. However, there are some caveats to my recommendation. -The roguelite is really light. There is low variation of rooms and you'll start to see repeats earlier than you'd expect. -Not huge enemy variety, there is a set of ~4 monsters per area that will rush you in increasingly larger and deadly waves. Combat usually boils down to button mashing and fleeing to recover your shields. -You can lose track of Eshe in the hordes as the camera can zoom pretty far out. Still, I enjoyed it a bunch and other than a bit of grinding I decided to do at the end (really easy to do with the skills you can unlock from the tree, picture below) I finished it at ~13 hours, making it a nice length for the multiple playthroughs if you choose to do them.", "appid": "535480", "steamid": "profiles/76561197977469997", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1573214400.0}

{"text": "It's hard to overstate what a magnificent exploration and adventure game Subnautica is. What really stands out to me is that experienceâ€”not an XP bar, but the accumulation of knowledge about the game world, its locations, and its inhabitantsâ€”is the most powerful weapon in a player's arsenal. Take Stalkers, for example: They're the first large predators a player will meet, and initially they're annoying and seem quite threatening. An experienced player will ignore them, though, or at most circle and poke them with a knife to make them go away, while at the same time stealing all of their scrap. It helps to have upgraded swim fins, upgraded O2, and other advantages, but if you took upgraded fins and O2 tanks away from experienced players, they still wouldn't have any issues with Stalkers. There's a lot to find and a lot to do in this game. The need to unravel the game's central mysteries and to obtain blueprint fragments, salvage, and rare materials from wrecks, grottoes, and strange installations will force you to leave your comfort zone time and again. First you'll crawl out of the Safe Shallows, then you'll creep further and deeper, then you'll swim further still until one day you'll be amazed at how far away from Lifepod 5 you've gone, at the readout on your depth meter, and you'll wonder how you ever thought that the seaweed areas just outside of the Safe Shallows were in any way scary. Sustenance is a challenge at first, and you'll scramble to get enough food and water, but later on they become a matter of management and planning ahead. If you're going on a long expedition, you'll want enough supplies to last for the duration, but not so many that you can't haul a goodly amount of salvage back to base. As for fiddly stuff, you can spend hours building and customizing your underwater habitat, customize the look and module loadout of the various vehicles you can build (once you've got the complete blueprints and necessary materials), and have a lot of fun with the wide array of gadgets and Portal/Half-Life-style \"techno-guns\" the game has to offer. There's a lot of meat there, but the true meal lies in exploration. Even at the very end of the game, though, armed with all the technology you've spent hours pulling out of wrecks and scanning (typically while watching your O2 meter like a hawk and listening nervously to that angry predator thrashing around outside), you'll never feel completely safe or at ease. There are great dangers lying in wait, and you'd better hope you spot them on your sonar before their sonar catches wind of you....", "appid": "578080", "steamid": "profiles/76561198069911410", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1516708800.0}

{"text": "Free-to-play, addictive, never-ending, time consuming, now somewhat open-world. What else do you want with a game? With this fast pace and shorter mission structure the game gives off a similar feel to Destiny or Diablo 3. This means it can be slightly repetitive at times but to break that continuous loop we are given a vaste library of locations, enemies and objective. Not bringing in the fact of having many limited-time events and special missions this game brings to the table. You can never find a time where there is nothing you could be doing. Trying to grind hard on a mission to get that one component for another Warframe or getting involved with your clan and going on raids to get that extra unlock for labs. There is tons to do and even more things to explore.  There is nothing more bad-ass than a space ninja ripping and tearing through thousands of enemies, this game will bring you that along with cool combos and skins. The constantly brings new looks with every update so you will never get tired of looking the same, coupled with the color palletes you can buy. You will never find the same ninja rolling around and devestating enemies.  The game is very difficult and uneasy to get into however because of how much there is to do and learn. it scares new-comers away but with how nice the community is there is little you cannot ask and get answered. Do not let the learning curve be a determining factor in this as by the time you get to harder missions the basics will be natural. There is at no point you will not be learning something new in this game.  This game will bring you to tears of joy and sorrow, make your face beet red with anger but most importantly it will bring you joy. Stick with the program and become the best ninja you can, learn from others so that one day you can become the ninja master training the new ninjas who wish to join the greatest free-to-play game of all time.", "appid": "230410", "steamid": "profiles/76561198249972626", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1550491200.0}

{"text": ";  - Interesting story for an FPS. Main character is tasked with bringing in a missing colonel, only to slowly lose his mind. It's basically the movie Apocalypse Now, minus the jungle. - Well-designed environments and atmosphere - Squad commands let you give your two teammates basic orders (attack, stun). Useful when you need some covering fire. - Some interesting gameplay mechanics. Dubai is full of sand. You can use this environmental element to your advantage. Maneuver around a sandstorm to take out enemies or temporarily stun a foe with sand from an errant grenade.   - Good choice of music. As you go deeper in the campaign, it changes appropriately to fit the mood. - Well-optimized performance. Very easy to run. :     - Zero replayability. Max two playthroughs if you're going for the FUBAR achievement and to collect any missing collectible intel. Once you're done, you're done. Multiplayer is uninspiring and by 2020, dead. - The graphics are dated-- low resolution cutscenes as well as generic character models and animations. This wasn't much of a looker even in 2012. The detailed environments are a nice touch though and add to the experience. - Generic shooting and cover mechanics. Plays like your typical, modern-day FPS.  : - Enemy & teammate AI is abysmal. Both sides leave themselves open to bullets, while the latter aren't really useful until you give them a command. If you need a quick 5-6 hour romp while you're sitting in quarantine and can get Spec Ops: The Line on deep discount, I'd recommend picking it up.", "appid": "50300", "steamid": "profiles/76561198019696234", "voted_up": true, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1586692800.0}

{"text": "The first game of a planned quadrilogy was colored in shades of brown and yellow, took place in a post-apocalyptic world. So the cheering green scenery of the first big location in the sequel is surprising. The contrast is obvious, but the result is a game looking like a starting WoW location. It still has those giant bosses, dungeons and enemies. But they seem to be so far away. What we have here is the new protagonist, the second horseman of the apocalypse â€” Death. His combat moves are quicker than Warâ€™s. He uses scythe as a starting weapon, of course. The combat itself is more focused on dodges than previously. The hero is faster, more agile, he has different tricks, like wall-running. When it comes to character interaction or the attitude of solving problems itâ€™s good old comic angst and vengeance again. This is the right combination of all the components of a badass action, but before youâ€™ll see any of that youâ€™ll have to deal with the problems of the locals, who look like giant dwarves. And those giant dwarves called Makers instead of angels and demons are supposedly very important. They establish the lore beyond that oh-â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥-apocalypse-happened straightforward premise.The game takes place right after the events of the prologue of the first one. So these are the final days of apocalypse starting prematurely. So what better place to start asking questions about what the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ is happening than the land of Architects of Creation? The answers though arenâ€™t compelling enough to overcome the boredom of a slow-paced start structured like a tutorial. This is your first new ability, this is the second. Here are all the old ones. Now thereâ€™s a lot of loot with color-coded rareness of items, crafting, systems. Side-quests, experience points, dungeons, chests â€” the game is really busy with showing all of its mechanics one by one. It takes several hours to go over this, but then it finally ends with the fantastic over-the-top boss-fight with a giant stone golem. You ride around like a hero of a western on your horse shooting weak points with your revolver (which, of course, is faster than the one War used in the first game). Hitting the target enough times gives you an opportunity to climb the giant, reach the real weak point and smash it. Not really original, but nicely executed and engaging. And this sums up the whole game.  Deathâ€™s design is a muscular version of Raziel from Soul Reaver. Thatâ€™s among a million of other things the game had ripped off. Grotesque mash-up still has its own tone. When the game picks itself up after the prologue absurdity kicks in. Itâ€™s the equivalent of a Marvel movie: stupid, with a breathtaking action scenes and with a distinct comic feel. Again, not that surprising knowing the guy behind it. Currently Joe Madureira is working on a game based on his own comic series Battle Chasers which ended with a cliffhanger in 2001. This is perhaps what has turned most people off: the game was exactly what everyone expected it to be. It does all the right things, adds new mechanics, develops the story. And yet its design as much as it is a pleasure to look at is the only force thatâ€™s holding it together. Itâ€™s sometimes stretched too thin, but it holds up as an arc of a bigger story. Though itâ€™s hardly possible that there will be a proper sequels after THQ bankruptcy. Rights to the franchise ended up inside Deep Silver. The team behind the first two games is gone, and the only definite thing going on is a HD-release of the second game for PS4 and Xbox One. Considering that Lords of Shadow 2 flopped with just five digit sales figures (and THQ complained about Darksiders II 1.5 million), this particular branch of 3D-metroidvanias seems to be in decline. Ironically that leaves hardcore Souls series as the only player on the market. Itâ€™s a sequel that can be described as expansive. It adds more of everything and on top of that it has numerous DLCs. But all of the flaws canâ€™t make scythes less cool and action less intense. In the end game completes the cycle and ends right where the first one did. {"text": "Real RPG with an actual medieval setting. It has the mix of map-exploring from paradox games like EUIV, CK2, HOIIV etc, tactical battle from Total War series, and the immersion from rpg like Skyrim. That's honestly awesome despite being 10 year old game.  I already knew this game for quite some time but never force myself into it because from i've seen it looked pretty clunky and old. Now with the coming of bannerlord and how it progressed i finally force myself into buying this again and damn all of my false asumptions and conjecture fell apart immediately, this game is pretty good especially if you like medieval warfare and settings. Not to mention there's ton of mods created by the beloved community (like real tons) that has total conversion from the native fictional map to real historical map in certain date and era. Like my favorite one the gekokujo mod that took place during Sengoku Jidai war, the 12th mod that took place during the advent of Mongol Conquest, or Crusades against Jihad mod that took place in the time of Crusader's invasion. All in all, if you like the games i mentioned above, you will definetely like this one. Don't get turned off because the graphic and UI (you can improve it with mods anyway to be more slightly tolerable). {"text": "Bridge Constructor always comes up with well-thought-out ideas and reasons for building bridges. Then once in a medieval style, or with educational purposes, or simply combine with 'Portal' because it is fun. This time we can enjoy a 'TWD' version where the bridge you will build will be decisive for your survival. The walkers may be stupid, but they understand the functions of a bridge perfectly. For this reason you will sometimes have to break the bridge you built with traps so that the walkers can also be disabled. Painful if the bridge was complicated to build, but survival above all else. {"text": "was basically a new experience for me, as I never tried the rest of the series properly. I was excited to give it a go as I found the gameâ€™s premise interesting, and the colonial setting is quite rare. Unfortunately, I just forced myself to continue playing it after a few hours because all the mechanics are repetitive without any interesting addition that would make me want to carry on with the game. It does not manage to use the potential of the gameâ€™s mechanicsâ€™ foundations. And that is truly a shame. The gameâ€™s setting takes place during the 16th and 17th centuries, where four European powers:  , and the  , compete for control over the  . While the game slightly follows some of the historical events, it does not have a storyline, so you form your own by your actions. At the start, you choose one of the four characters types, like a merchant or an adventurer, and your own flag. And that is it. You cannot change anything else, like appearance. Not like that it matters, because there is nothing else apart from the three starting characterâ€™s statistics. Your chosen person does not exist in the game, as you cannot assign them anywhere, level up its traits or something. There is nothing. It seems that you are also stuck with your chosen faction, as you cannot switch sides or become independent. I would expect that, in such a game, my character would be important. The opposite is actually the case, as it is just a gimmick feature. It is also a shame that there are no native Americans or the topic of slavery. That was a part of daily life back then. Instead, the game presents it like:  . I am not saying that I want a simulation of racial discrimination and conflicts, but ignoring it and presenting it the way the game does it is not the best solution either. The game offers a decent tutorial, which I recommend to all newcomers. As for the campaigns, there is each for every faction. However, the first campaign for Spain, which you need to finish before being able to play as other nations, feels like a  , in which you can do whatever you want. There is just a list of tasks you have to do, like:  . Sure, there are scripted events like the arrival of a certain pirate, but that is not enough. There is no motivation for finishing the campaign, as there is no proper goal. You could argue that you should create your own goal, but there is already the abovementioned   for that, so what is the point of the campaign then? You start in your hometown city with some money and a simple goal in mind. You have to expand your business to become rich. The only person above you is viceroy, who supervises your factionâ€™s colonies. He permits you privileges, like getting warships, administrate other towns, or to be able to run businesses. To get access to those privileges, you need to become more famous, so you have to complete other cityâ€™s tasks, trade, and fight. The problem is that those tasks revolve around things you would do anyway: trading and fighting. Then there are activities like finding someoneâ€™s relative in the sea and treasure hunting. And that is it. All those tasks and activities monotonously repeat constantly. There is also no proper diplomacy and relationships with other cities or your viceroy. There could be done way more with the colonial setting to make the game more interesting, yet it looks like they did not even try. Every city produces a certain amount of commodities, and you can increase it by building appropriate businesses for it. Those commodities vary from food, mining resources, and handicraft ones. In the cities you own, you have to arrange housing, pubs, churches, and other buildings for your workers. It is crucial to place them properly, as there are bonuses to production and residentsâ€™ happiness. It certainly cannot compete with city-building titles, such as the  , as those are more complex, but I think it is enough for this kind of game. Just do not expect to beautify your city. The trading itself is quite disappointing, and that is a problem as the game presents it as one of the main features. It works simply. For example, if a city produces a lot of wood, you buy it there and sell it to the city that requires it. The problem is that you can already see every cityâ€™s production and prices from the start of the game. You do not have to find it out first. And other cities and factions do not seem to compete with you either. It proved to be most shallow in the campaign, as enemy pirate did not even attack my defenseless ships full of expensive commodities. There is just no depth in it. You can do it manually, which is very tedious and repetitive after a while. There is an option to automize this process by creating trade routes, which do everything for you. Then you just sit for hours, occasionally build a new business or accept a task, and that is it. So, the main gameplay mechanic, trading, is either repetitive and boring, or you can automize it, so the game plays on its own. You can take part in naval combat, which is probably the most enjoyable part of the game. However, it is still simple. It has a turn-based form on a hex grid field where only four vs. four ships can fight. I did not find a way to add additional reinforcements, which were right next to the battle on the worldâ€™s map. During turns, you can move with your ship a few tiles, attack, or use some of the abilities which you get from the abovementioned cityâ€™s tasks. To be honest, I do not understand why I can repair my ship during the combat only if I completed delivering 40 boxes of bananas to another city before. Although the battles are a good addition, they do not require much of tactical thinking. All in all, I truly like the gameâ€™s premise, but the way it all works is just tedious. There is no reason for me to continue playing it. I do not want to watch ships going back and forth for another twenty hours without any twist. I do not want to find someoneâ€™s relative for the 50th time. I do not want to build a random building, so the viceroy would tell me how I made colonies a better place again. I would say that the visuals look good, as the game is quite colourful, as you would expect from a Caribbean setting. The sound effects are okay, and the soundtrack is fitting but a bit repetitive, so I would not mind having more diverse compositions. However, I expected that there would be more animations, like that the ships would actually dock into a harbor, or at least send boats with resources. They are just floating in the sea instead. The game was tested with an  , running at the highest settings, at  , at  . The frame drops are totally random and unrelated to any specific activity, which made my playthrough annoying.  definitely has good foundations for its gameplay elements. However, none of those have any depth, and thus the game becomes monotonous and repetitive quite soon. There is simply no motivation for me to continue playing it.", "appid": "1024650", "steamid": "profiles/76561198111956371", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "57", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1602072000.0}

{"text": "Wutachtalbahn is a pleasant route going through German countryside. Unfortunately there's a great many problems, but there's a few positive things as well. I'm giving this a negative review because of the many broken scenarios and achievements. I buy content almost exclusively for the scenarios it comes with, and for that purpose, this dlc is completely broken. If you're buying it to create your own content, go for it. The lowered price reflects the fact that you only get one locomotive (but it's a good one), the dated scenery and the relatively short route. Most of it is 40-50km limits so it still takes a while to drive end to end and there's a few sidings which would allow some creativity I think - something that is largely unused in the default scenarios. Had it not been for the scenario problems, I would have quite enjoyed running this route.  One significant thing of note:  There are a number of complaints in reviews stating that the signage for speed limits isn't there. Ignore them; it is. They're just relying on the HUD only. There is two spots where the speed changes on the track and it doesn't show up on the HUD, but the signage is next to the track alerting the astute driver to the upcoming changes.  + The locomotive. It's a pleasure to drive! It's not complicated but it's textures are good, and the sounds aren't bad - at least by TS standards. The locomotive really is the best part of this package. + There's not a lot of rolling stock, but what comes with it works and isn't bad. + The route is pretty, tho the assets are dated. That also means the frame rate is wonderfully high through the entire thing.  + The scenarios do not knock you with points if the locomotive slips, which is fortunate, since it does slip a lot. Unfortunately, the negatives are just too much to wade through (for me) which is quite sad. This route could have been so nice! I did overall enjoy it but I just can't give a positive review to something so shoddily put together and that has not been patched in 3 yrs as of this writing.  - Most of the scenarios are broken in one way or another. One scenario only has 3 checkpoints with 200 points each making it impossible to finish correctly. Another confiscates points for being late even when you are 2 minutes early. I don't understand how that happens. Even looking in the editor everything looks correct, yet when I arrived a solid 2 min early I got a sudden 4000 point negative hit for being late. I ran it again and had the same problem, tho I was slightly faster and a slightly smaller negative hit. A couple of them have the old problem of just not registering points. That'll probably be ok with some people who don't care about the achievements or career levels. One scenario has 2 too many check points, so you can get up to 400 points taken away and still end with 1000.  - As I mentioned above, the textures are old but the route can be pretty. The major problems are when you come up to a tunnel and it's blocked by the side of the mountain. I can't understand why this is still a thing... You can drive through it of course, but.... c'mon. Still sloppy. - Because of the aforementioned scenario problems, half the achievements are broken. Either because the scenario gives you points, the scenario doesn't allow you to get the number of points required for the achievement, or in the case of 8600 points total, there is not that many points obtainable in the dlc. Overall its plagued largely by scenario problems that in most cases, would only take a few minutes to fix.", "appid": "562378", "steamid": "profiles/76561198072113884", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "7", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1602417600.0}

{"text": "Oik is a series of simple physics (primarily gravity, incorporating momentum and friction) puzzles designed to appeal less to people that want to play physics puzzles and more to people that want to use the bountiful symbolic (mostly letters & numbers on different coloured backgrounds) Steam Achievements to decorate their profiles and those that value their Avg. Game Completion Rate and look upon their percentage with pride, regardless of how they got there.  The puzzles are small and simple enough to generally be soluble within a couple of trial and error attempts:  a considered analytical approach is not really required.  I found only one puzzle amongst the 67 that required some thought, and I was able to accumulate all 201 achievements well before receiving all of the Steam Trading Cards dropped for playing.  As such, I do not recommend this to puzzle aficionados, except perhaps to hold in reserve for a fairly unsatisfying ego boost on a bad day. {"text": "You'll likely read a lot of comparisons between Villagers & Banished. And for good reason. Both are Medieval City-Builders and both sell around the â‚¬20 mark, with Banished selling at â‚¬18.99 and Villagers at â‚¬19.99. There is no contest. Banished is highly regarded, while Villagers is an entirely underwhelming experience. A long-winded, convoluted and tedious story begins when your character, by virtue of their natural-born \"City planning\" skills, is tasked with building a village. Each mission serves as part-tutorial with new features and buildings added with each new settlement you move to. Invariably each mission involves setting up your town hall, and gathering resources before some deus ex machina prompts you and your village to move along to somewhere else. The shortcomings don't just end with the story-line though, where Villagers really falls flat is the lack of depth and difficulty. There are very few specialist buildings and very little micromanagement involved. For some, this could be a plus, with Villagers definitely offering a more casual experience than Banished, but for myself, it falls short of what I look for in a city-builder. In terms of presentation and UI, Villagers offers a fairly simple interface thanks to it's lack of depth and the graphics are OK. I would expect users to have few problems running Villagers, visually it offers nothing remarkable or demanding. In short Villagers is an expensive, casual city-builder, with a poor story and unremarkable features. And being priced more than Banished results in a disappointing experience. {"text": "Ghoststory is one of the most \"walky\" / plodding / meandering, slow and generic of all Walking Sim or First Person Adventure games I have ever played. The narrator rambles incessantly about a bunch of random â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you have no idea what he's even referring to as you wander through bland environments at a snail's pace. While I don't mind the lack of a run button for this genre of game, do I really have to be penalized for daring to divert off of the one linear path the game intended for hoping there might be something different to look at (or interact with, collect... anything) down a separate path? Just another bland dead end that I then have to slowly backtrack to the one throughline to progress? Which is an apt metaphor for this game's shallow, woeful dialog.  I don't mind the Walking Sim genre's slower pace but give me something to look at beyond a dark tunnel or generic forest environment for the first half hour if all I'm going to be doing is listening to the narrator ramble incessantly about nothing of any particular consequence or interest. An auto-walk toggle to just have the character automatically move forward would be nice in such leisurely titles, rather than having to obnoxiously sit there holding the W key constantly.   While the game's graphics and environments look nice, Ghoststory will seldom ever give you a passage of time without the narrator ranting about some garbage that oozes faux profundity. {"text": "Disclaimer: Key provided by developer for review purposes. Then I got stuck.  I saved and reloaded the game, but still stuck in the same spot.  I quit the game and go to the discussions area to investigate the problem and see the only solution is to load the last checkpoint   exiting the game. {"text": "Honestly, past the hype train, I feel like I got robbed. Glad other users on here have seen this, since pro journos can't be trusted. Gameplay: First person really doesn't work well. Difficulty is laughable, even playing in first person with all aim assist turned on. Enemies take multiple hits, and you are a tank. There's lots of standing in the open and shooting at each other from 10 feet away, out of cover, shaving off health with multiple shots. Basically gives everything a very low energy, low pressure feeling even with all assists turned off, so that you feel no excitement. The whole experience just feels like a chore. Free aim is terribly clunky, and hit detection is something they still haven't got the hang of without lock on turned on. I'm a very mediocre gamer, and this was one of the easiest game I've played, and not in a good way. Enemies are identical in behavior and armament, and don't behave organically enough to justify the sameness on the grounds of \"realism\". Last but not least, a lot of boring riding through the same forested landscape. Its wants to be the Witcher but lacks the beauty, variety, and depth of the countryside. It also can't get off its own shaft, and constantly make you ride the same area and pause so the developers can jerk themselves and make you look at their masterpiece. Never though, did I have organic moment like in other games where I stopped to admire. Story: Bad. But I have a much higher bar for stories than most people, while my gameplay bar is about average. Still if you like HBO stuff more than say FOX or NBC, the story will disappoint. It's the same tragic tale as last time, with very inconsistently written characters. The dialogue is great in some cases, but the overall story is very lacking. The biggest issue is the attempt to paint Arthur as the good guy, vs just a likeable bad guy. When you murder 700 law abiding government officials, its hard to portray the guy as a classic hero, but try they do. To make it doable, the employ the laziest method ever, which is to make everyone else racist, and Arthur and his gang of barely literate horse thieves and prostitute feminists and equality centric. Why is it okay that Arthur is killing trains full of 18 year US Army personal just doing a job? Oh, because they are, every one of them racists, so now Arthur the murdering thieve is a nice guy do-gooder. Dumb + lazy writing. Makes me wish for Niko again. Didn't pretend to be a good guy any more than Scarface, so when he thinned out the ranks of the NYPD, it still made sense. Value for money: Low. They claim like 200 hours in bonus activity, but this isn't the case. You end the game with tons of money, with nothing in the game world to spend it on. Even if you did have something worth buying, you wouldn't be able to make it. All side activities pay very poorly. Robbing a store (banks are not robbable???) pays 30$, meanwhile the bounty you'll rack up escaping will be a minimum of 400$ bounty if you want to have any fun, and you can lose thousands if you die. Bounties pay nothing, like 80$ on average, and hunting fishing is boring (somehow the only viable option is with a bow, and you there are so many animals you can just ride up to them and dead eye, making it pointless to go looking) and pays very little. Stick ups pay 50 cents, and always go the same way. Poker games are limited to 5$, also making them pointless. I think the reason the post game feels so dead is to force people into online.", "appid": "1174180", "steamid": "profiles/76561198074085825", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "22", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1575633600.0}

{"text": "This will be my first (and hopefully last) thumbs-down review. Firstly, the story is great (coming from someone who has not watched/read any GoT material) Graphics are not the best, but it's quite alright. They look like their characters in the TV series (lol) The story is really intense, every choice that you have to make puts you in a spot and urges you to consider carefully. I have completed the whole game, and I think I have made some of the worst choices. The ending I got was terrible (also the least %) Apart from that, when looking at it as a whole, there is also no sense of satisfaction at all. It just leaves you feeling frustrated. Can't really say much more without spoiling it. So I guess you should only get this game if 1) You have NEVER watched/read any GoT material (so you appreciate the story and action more) 2) You are up for an interesting and intense story adventure 3) You don't mind feeling frustrated after the whole thing is over (frustration levels may differ) 4) You want the achievements 5) The game is on sale. When its 75% off. I do like one thing though (that is consistent) - the opening theme.  Disappointed with Telltale for this one. {"text": "I hate this one. I hate how it seems to have everything in it to be actually good, but isn't. I am torn. I like the characters, I like the fact that there are tons of characters to romance, I like the routes (though some of them are just painful - looking at you, Doc), and while I wouldn't say that the overall plot is all that interesting, it's not so bad as to make me drop the game completely. There is, however, one glaring issue with this VN - and it's its main character.  I am no stranger to otomes with bland MCs with no free will of their own - it's something that often cannot be avoided in this particular genre. I'm not a fan, but it's usually okay. Unfortunately, in OZMAFIA!! we get that same bland MC with no free will of her own - but this time, she has one (1) defining characteristic: she's endearingly stupid. Yes. That is her feature. Stupid, ignorant, naive and incredibly sweet. Nice mix, wouldn't you say? So nice, in fact, that instead of a more or less mature female protagonist we end up with an oversized child as our main character. Do you see? In this game, you're basically playing as a child. {"text": "UPDATE -- I can no longer recommend this game on PC, as it is still broken and no longer being supported.  Content for other platforms is not being released on PC, and all PC development has stopped.  I have since bought it on PS4, and the difference in quality is astounding.  Unfortunately, all of the people who bought it on PS4 at release have an advantage and I find myself getting my butt kicked in online matches! Original review below: While I have really enjoyed MKX, it is not without its problems.  All in all, I recommend the game, but unless you are a die-hard fan it may be worth waiting until the glitches are fixed. Pros:  Each fighter has 3 variations, each with their own special attacks, brutalities, etc. Story mode is fun and gives you the chance to play several of the characters (twelve chapters, each chapter is one character, and you have 4 fights per chapter. The graphics are incredible. The fatalities and brutalities are really creative and also very gruesome. Faction Wars are interesting and give you new challenges every day. Cons: Online mode seems to be down every day. When online mode is up, it is very laggy. Game often crashes or freezes. {"text": "Edit on January 2018: Performance problems were never fixed on my end, devmode is still enabled no matter what, had to uninstall because I just don't think it's worth it any more. Really sad about this game. BEWARE SPOILERS!! My take on this game comes from two different places I wanna adress, but before that, keep in mind I -liked- the game, but as much as it pains me, I cannot recommend this title by any means unless it's on a big discount, or the current problems as of the day of this review are fixed. Having played through the main campaing AND having tried the Freedom Chronicles, I feel confident enough to say that The New Colossus is an unfinished game that needed more time. I will try to keep this simple, might edit stuff later. As a reference, here's my current rig: GTX 970, I7 4790k, 16gb RAM, 1920x1080 60Hz, with the last Nvidia driver, the 388.00 version. Performance: -On release day, game crashed when alt tabbing, when changing resolutions, got a couple BSODS while playing. -Game couldn't handle 1920x1080, as there was a configuration error with the DPI scaling  -Game worked pretty stable on Ultra, 60 fps and that, but anything beyond that had mayor FPS drop rates, which might be because my current GPU can't handle Uber (GTX 970). Some levels at the beginning were badly optimized -Game constantly corrupted my data, was unable to sync with the cloud, for some reason it doesn't detects the console 100% of the times, and because of that, you can't access your game profile, because it needs to be linked with your cloud. This happened a couple of times, and I believe is something that the developers should look at, if they're listening to the feedback at all. The Game: Story wise, I got pretty hooked on it from the beggining, it felt fresh and new, and I absolutely loved the character interactions and flavor between the npcs, it felt like a nice touch, with much more richer storytelling than New Order. It's the same ''blazko go blow this â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ up'' kind of momentum that NewOrder has. The game abruptely ends on what seemed to be the middle of the story, the finale lacking an end boss, and Blazko taking revenge on Frau Engel. The game offers the same beautiful shooting mechanics as NWO, and the game looks beautiful, but it's very, very short. It feels like a story was trying to be told, with cinematics every level, a backstory for Blazko, new characters, a definitive change of pace, but it doesn't feels like Wolfenstein, feels like something ELSE, and I think, had there been more time to add more content to the game, I wouldn't think that. It feels like watching a movie, one I really liked, but it doesn't feels like a complete shooter. Perks have changed completely, and some of them are almost useless in the game. In new order, it defined your playstyle, and it felt intuitive and natural to understand. Those features feel like achievements in The New Colossus, some of them are useful, some are not. There are weapon upgrades now, for every weapon that you own, except for the heavy weapons. These upgrades are almost MANDATORY to finish the game, especially if you're playing on Uber/Death Incarnate. Takedowns have stayed mostly the same, but the stealth on this game is UNFORGIVING. Some could say this is more realistic and challenging, I honestly don't know what they did to the stealth, but sometimes it doesn't makes sense, as enemies can see you even if you're hidden. When you finish the game, you can keep playing, and you get to hunt down Uberkommanders, visit locations, and get collectibles. If these were added into the main story, the game would had been very different. They're not a hassle, but story doesn't advances much after that.  Now, on the DLCS. Freedom chronicles comes with the preorder of the game, and it features mini stories for 3 different characters, each with different abilities and levels made for them. It also comes with combat simulations, something like challenge levels if you wanna play those. By the looks of it, it seems like this is scheduled to be released over time, to add content of the game. I don't mind having more content, (as the game on itself it's lacking some), but it makes you think why wasn't Freedom Chronicles a part of the main game. Overall, it feels like this game needed more time. Crashes and performance issues on release day, and well after WEEKS these problems keep happening. There is a huge problem with the in-game content, it really feels like Machinegames added features at the end of the game to give it some more lifespan, added with Freedom Chronicles and combat simulations. I cannot recommend this game, as much as I wanted to. Performance issues NEED TO BE FIXED, it is unacceptable that after 15 days since the game was released (currently at the time of this review), it seems like there's nothing going on to adress those issues. The new take on Wolfenstein is great, New Order was a gem, and The New Collosus brings new, interesting stuff to the table, and I'd love to keep playing and see what comes out of this story, but a broken game is still a broken game. Get this on discount, or don't get it at all, and expect things to break if you do. I will gladly change and modify this review over time if stuff changes, as for the moment, it's a toothless wolf that's stuggling to walk.", "appid": "612880", "steamid": "profiles/76561198028101737", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "3", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1510315200.0}

{"text": "Them - The Summoning is the first (and the last) entry in a proposed series, where you try to solve a murder mystery. Story: You play as Cian. One night your friend Grendel calls you urging you to come to his house right away, because something bad has happened and once you are there, he explains that his deceased wife Albea is haunting him and soon Grendel ends up dead and you're on the run trying to figure out what happened. The story overall is nothing to write home about. It has an interesting step up and some interesting twists at the end, but overall the writing is pretty sloppy. The game ends on a pretty big cliffhanger, with the game originally intending to be a trilogy, but due to poor sales, those plans were cancelled and we won't truly find out what has happened to these characters or what most of those set ups meant. Graphics: The game is a Hidden Object Game and if you have played one of those you know what to anticipate. Each screen is filled to the brim with a bunch of stuff and then you have to search for things from a list. One thing I expect at the very least is high resolution pictures in a game like this so I can find items. This game doesn't have that. The pictures are pretty low res and it makes finding items a really big pain in the ass. There's actually a few times a screen is reused with roughly any changes done to it. Another thing is the characters in the game are pictures of real life people which sort of don't fit in place with the rest, since they are slightly more high resolution, than the environments.  Audio: One thing that would have helped this game immensely is voice acting and there's none of it here. I would have even taken some cheesy acting, just something to break up the terrible audio design. First of all I'll talk about the music. It's not good whatsoever, most tracks sound incredibly generic and they are put on a very short loop. Another thing is when you click a lot of times in a HOG game, it will give you a sound cue that you clicked too much and it was so annoying that I tried to click as less as possible, just to not hear that sound. Gameplay: Them - The Summoning is a pure HOG game, meaning there's not much else for you to do here. Each level you through lists looking for items and then do it over and over until the game is over. There's some slight deviations on this formula when it asks you to find differences in a picture or click on something in a row and there's also bonus stuff you can find in each level to give you extras (which are not worth it, cause it just unlocks a replay of that level). There are some minor puzzles to solve, but I can barely call them puzzles, since they are so incredibly easy. Sometimes the game will literally tell you what to do. For example, the main character might say \"I need to find a hidden tunnel, maybe I should break that wall over there\". Those are the type of puzzles you will solve. I wish something more challenging was present.  The gameplay itself is super boring, not to mention with the low res graphics it was a pain to go through each level, looking for 20 items that basically blend into mush.  Verdict: Them - The Summoning is not worth it, even to the hardcore fans of HOG games. Story that will never have a wrap up, low res pictures making hunting for items a pain and incredibly short even for a HOG, barely lasting 90 minutes. If you want a HOG game to pass the time, look elsewhere. Final Rating: 3/10 Pros: + Semi interesting plot Cons: - Low Res textures make hunting items a pain  - Story ends on a cliffhanger, which is not going to get resolved  - Terrible audio design  If you liked this review please consider joining   and", "appid": "300510", "steamid": "profiles/76561198043609914", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "8", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1603972800.0}

{"text": "I love experimental games! Games that prove why video gaming is worth artistic investment. However, Schastye could have just as easily been a film or a book, and the primary reason for that is the infernal gameplay, which boils down to mindless mashing of keys. The core idea behind the game is brilliant, and I love the graphics and the space in the apartment. But the gameplay... The setting of the game is a small Russian apartment, decorated with a few bits and bobs. The core gameplay of the game is sitting down at a singular desktop and \"typing\" a story. But there's no prompt to see the next letter you have to type. If it had been a typing game even, the game would have been far more entertaining. The story itself is decent enough, as Lovecraftian short stories go, but the actual act of writing out the short story is painful. Since you don't know what letter is coming next, and guessing is almost pointless, you are left to frantically mash the keyboard or run your hands over the letters - which just serves to give the player physical pain. This must be why the somewhat mischievous \"good ending\" is just leaving the apartment before typing the story.  All in all, a decent experiment, but the \"game\" elements were poorly thought out. Physical pain from gaming, while perhaps a new sensation for me, was really just dissatisfactory in the end. Not a game that's worth the pain, sadly. Other experimental games have done more - but I must admit I will keep tabs on the developer, who showed a lot of promise with this game! A simple refinement of the gameplay would make the game an instant recommendation for this price.", "appid": "1392170", "steamid": "profiles/76561198062739674", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "4", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1605700800.0}

{"text": "Full Disclosure: A key was provided by the developers for review purposes. \t  is a first person one versus all multiplayer experience that takes a radical departure from from the shooter genre.  Boasting a controversial gimmick where the game servers will shut down indefinitely when the total number of lives run out (as of now, around 215 million), the concept behind   is unique, to say the least.  However, given how difficult it even is to find a match online due to the woefully empty player base, there's no chance of the game ending any time in the near future. \tAll of that aside,   manages only to excel in mediocrity.  There is all but one game mode, a one vs all where players  vie to find the light artifact and fend off the other players, the shadow monsters .  Only three maps are available at the moment, so   does feel a bit light on content. Barring the short tutorial, the game is multiplayer only, yet even finding an active game has been an exercise in futility given the almost non-existent player base. \tIf you actually do manage to find a game, upon entering the match, the players are thrust into the role of shadow creatures, racing each other to the light artifact to become the light carrier.   The light carrier can kill the shadows with their movement based kinetic powered light gun (a flashlight), though shadows are immune when they aren't moving.   The person who survives as the light bearer the longest wins the game, so itâ€™s a relatively simple game in execution.   \tThe controls, though relatively easy to master are clunky at best, and the game as a whole feels slow in execution.  Maps feel too large to find players, and the movement as a shadow monster feels a bit disorienting with the amount of head bobbing (though this can be turned off in the options).  The graphics and sound don't fare much better either, and while serviceable, are not exactly anything to write home about.  When it works, the game's presentation is acceptable, yet bland overall.   \tThere are a myriad of technical problems in the game as well, some crippling, and some just annoying.  I experienced several crashes to the desktop and black screens when attempting to start the game or join a match.  In its current state, it seems to be a gamble whether the game will work or not, though some issues encountered could unlikely be due to Windows 10. \tEither way, it would be difficult to recommend   in its current state.  There's not much content in the game, and given its relatively high price on the Steam Store ($16.99/â‚¬16.99), this game should be skipped unless you're the type of person that enjoys frustration.  Though the concept remains an interesting one, the lack of an online community ultimately kills this bland multiplayer-only title.   \tOverall, a  . {"text": "Well, that was disappointing. Jessica Valiant, AKA Agent Silent Death, is the protagonist of Wolfenstein 2's newest DLC episode, and I was initially taken aback by the surprisingly introspective narration. Jessica's voice actor exudes a gushingly charismatic persona through her hard-drinking and smoke-deepened, acidic voice, but there was ultimately nothing of value to reap in this 90-minute choad of a pseudo-sci-fi tale. The environmental level designs are perfunctory and forgettable, and combat offers absolutely nothing new to fans who've played through the base campaign. I completed all 3 levels of this DLC on the hardest difficulty, without breaking a sweat for an entire hour until the last 60 seconds or so when the difficulty spiked out of nowhere, as your fragile self is forced to run through crowded and claustrophobic rooms in a race to the finish line. I loved Wolfenstein 2's campaign. Sure, there's tons of glaring issues to poke fun at, but as a whole, I felt like I got my money's worth, and more. It's therefore quite unfortunate to watch such esteemed developers, Machine Games, dole out crappy DLC, one after the other. {"text": "This is a nice adventure game. The story is somewhat interesting, the dialogues have depth and give the characters some gravity, there are some funny lines and references, graphics-atmosphere is cute and it's good value for money..  , but there's one \"combined\" reason why it gets a thumbs down: The gameplay system is making it a small torture! If you accidentally click a person or a dialogue option or a place where there will be some kind of response, be that a dialogue or some action in the place, there's   (there's some fast-forward if you keep \"action\" pressed but that's not enough). You just have to endure the repeated dialogue/actions which shows no respect for the player's time. This is something very high on my list of reasons to give a thumbs down, mostly to alarm people for what to expect (and maybe for devs to fix it). Similarly if a scene is starting (and you need to click to advance of course) there's no way to skip it or even pause to save and replay at another time. Same for scene transitions (that \"Shisa\" is moving slower than a turtle! ).. Even when switching between locations there's a considerable delay which, given the simplicity of the graphics, isn't justified. To recap: The game is fun! {"text": "This game is very atmospheric and has one of the best fighting systems I've ever seen in an RPG. But...and the \"but\" is really big.....the controls are extremely messed up. Don't buy this game without having a controller. The keyboard and mouse bindings are as intuitive as algebra while being drunk. I have played a lot of difficult games and I always push myself to finish the challenge, but I'm really struggling in this game with my frustration. Not because you die too fast or too often - I have experienced worse - it's because the biggest challenge, the hardest enemy to overcome, are the controls. Nothing killed me more than simply being unable to move like I want my character to move. My deaths due to gravity together with stuff like hiding behind your shield and wanting to step backwards only to suddenly turn around and exposing your vulnerable back because you forgot to \"lock on\" to your enemy in front of you killed me more than anything else. Das Spiel befindet sich zur Zeit im Early-Access sollte aber bereits seit einem Jahr fertiggestellt worden sein und den Early-Access verlassen haben. Die Grafik ist einfach gemacht. Jeder, der auch nur einmal Darts im Fernsehen geschaut hat, sprich bei professionellen Spielern gesehen hat, weiÃŸ, dass der Wurf in die \"Triple 20\" die hÃ¶chsten Punkte bringt. {"text": "Immortal: Unchained is essentially Dark Souls with guns; that is if Dark Souls were one of the worst RPG games of its time. It tries so hard to copy the formula established by Souls series but it also tries to force ranged mechanics into it that clearly don't fit. The result is an unfair and frustrating experience that isn't fun at all. Enemies can hit you from far away and outside your view with their projectiles and it doesn't help that the levels are often spammed with so many enemies that they could essentially kill you instantly if they hit at the same time. Level design is one of the worst I've seen in a long time, maps are unnecessarily large for no reason other than to pad out the play time and make room for spamming enemies randomly in every inch of empty space. The sense of exploration is crushed by endless hordes of enemies with guns that have pinpoint accuracy. The second location, Veridian, is one of the most rage-inducing levels that I've played in a video game for a very long time. Not because it's challenging, but because it's plain unfair and poorly thought through. There simply isn't much thought put into designing levels or tweaking enemies, as a result the game is insanely difficult because it's just unfair. Enemy types are basically defined by their weapons which vary in projectile speed and damage. Melee combat is so bad it may as well not exist at all. There are no combos or attack types, the melee button is basically a hit with clunky animation and pre-defined damage. Boss battles are essentially all the same; you dodge their attacks to the side, get behind their back and shoot their weakspot.  Overall, this game is total waste of time for anyone except the most die-hard Souls fans that have an everlasting hard-on for difficult games. Unless the only thing you care about is how hard a game is, I can't recommend buying this even on a sale. - Insane plot twists - Beautiful art design - Free soundtrack DLC - Good equipment and item variety - Excellent voice acting and decent audio quality - Great progression system and role-playing elements - Extremely difficult - Indirect story telling - Poor balance - No pause ability - Horrible graphics - Awful level design - Garbage melee combat - Frustrating gameplay mechanics - Unoriginal story and weak presentation - Repetitive and uninteresting boss battles - Terrible performance and bad optimization  5.75/10 - Poor Immortal: Unchained is a rather poor execution of the Souls-like formula with frustrating gameplay mechanics such as slow reload times, clunky controls, terrible level design and unfair balancing that is not an enjoyable experience in the slightest. Every aspect of the game is handled poorly, from gameplay to graphics and optimization. Not recommended at all, avoid this game even on sales.", "appid": "369440", "steamid": "profiles/76561197963259080", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "8", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1542888000.0}

{"text": "Is that a thumbs down? Yup. But don't let that fool you. This is still a great game, but there's reasons. Let me explain. The Negatives: Epic has risen it's evil head and forced Psyonix to ruin the item system, â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ over it's customer base, and (in turn) hurt the community it built. Before Season 5, crates were awarded that could be unlocked with a key that was $1 assuming you bought 5+ keys. This gave you a random item of varying quality, just like any standard loot crate, or more comparatively, CS-GO's crate system. Once Season 5 hit, they introduced blueprints, which you would get after random matches. These blueprints could be an item of any varying quality. However, it now costs credits to create those items, price being dependent on the quality of an item. For instance, a common item would be 100 credits, and Black Market items would be 2000 credits. The problem? 100 Credits = $1, or in comparison, 1 key. That means you need TWENTY keys to make a Black Market item. While, it's possible you could not get a Black Market item within 20 keys in the old system, you still got 20 other items of varying quality for your vehicles. Terrible, right? To make matters worse, Psyonix/Epic decided to spit on their community further by recently releasing price adjustments using a standard scumbag practice of pricing super high, only to mark it down to a price that still scams their customer base, but appears like a good deal because of the significant price drop, allowing (dumb) customers to think they're actually getting a deal and forgetting that they gained so much more via the old system.  The Positives: The game itself is still good. {"text": "I played it for almost an hour and completed a scenario. Here are my thoughts. It was fun. It was like playing the old classic games in the series. There were some improvements compared to the original like how the handyman no longer has mowing the grass option on by default. So seeing those pesky employees endlessly mowing the grass is no longer a thing. And that's fantastic. I'm glad they carried that change over. The food stands also direct themselves automatically towards paths, which I personally like. It made some work slightly more efficient. And they also have an updated front menu showing off all the different scenarios and that really helps to put into perspective how much time you could easily put into this game to finish them all. There is also a scenario editor on top of all this! Last, but not least, I'm sure many Mac OS owners would also be pleased with this game because unlike the original two games, this game IS compatible with Macs. Now, despite enjoyment and praise, there are still some problems that would become problematic and more annoying over time. My biggest issues were with the updated UI and the number of generated cars/logs etc on rides. Trying to get my ride to go from test to off took an unnecessary number of clicking. For a while I didn't even know where to go to save my game either. I understand that some of these changes were probably made to make it work better with touch controls, but on a desktop it results in needless movements. For example, a ride I made ended up with the maximum number of cars at the start. 28 logs on a platform that supported ~18. I had to try and test the ride multiple times to get the number down a bit, which comes back to the unnecessary number of clicks to change the ride from test to off because it cycles from off to test to on to off again. Now, that doesn't sound bad. Sounds like the handyman problem, right? Well, if you don't change it for rollercoasters, there is the likelihood of an accident occurring. And that's annoying. I also had some issues with the full screen not being full screen and my direction keys not functioning the way they would have in previous games. Having to be careful while trying to go to different parts of my theme park was not quite what I expected nor wanted to have to keep in mind while playing. I have a tri-monitor setup, so moving my mouse too much in either direction would cause it to go onto another monitor. Manually click the globe directions was a bit of a pain too. They were a 2D graphics that didn't fully make sense when viewing in 3D.  From the above, I think I've made my point that the UI needs tweaking. It's just not that good. It could be better if more time was spent on it, and at that point I could totally recommend this game, but as it is right now it's not something I could recommend. This game has no achievements; it's basically a compilation of the first two games and their expansions, and the UI isn't very good for desktop users. If the Toolkit were connected with Steam Workshop that would have also added a lot more value and prolonged the interest in this game; think Cities: Skylines or even Super Mario Maker for the Wii U/3DS. For touch screen controls, it could be slightly better, but I imagine someone else having the same issue I had above with the cart/log generation and then I just don't feel I could recommend it like that because it's tedious.  Closing comment: You might be better off buying the original two games, which are also on Steam, as at least that way some of the problems in those games can be forgiven due to their age. It's a lot harder to do that here. Fixing this game's UI, and a implementing a proper ride cart/log generation system would go a very long ways to making this game a recommended buy.", "appid": "683900", "steamid": "profiles/76561198064092607", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "6", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1543060800.0}

{"text": "This game is kinda fun for a short period of time but it has three issues that I can't look past. The first and the least important is that in later waves your screen is so full of crap that it's impossible to work what is going on so it's pretty well impossible to place or upgrade towers midwave when you get up to wave 80+. The second and far more important issue is that this game is ultra-grindy. You will need to grind both XP and Monkey Money to progress through the upgrade tree and Monkey Money for things like powers you can use in game and new heroes. The progress is very slow and this game gets boring before you get to any of the interesting upgrades. Another thing is that this game has the most grindy achievements of any tower defense game I've ever played by a long, long way. If you are thinking that you can do some efficient farming here, you are wrong, the \"Fast Forward\" option is quite slow so even if you come across a map and a good strategy, you will be farming for a very long time to get anywhere. The most important problem is this game's microtransactions. This game is pay to win by definition. You can buy both Monkey Money and knowledge points which means that you can instantly unlock the upgrade trees without farming for a decade and the very substantial advantages in those trees. It also means that you can buy powers and insta-monkeys so you would have a massive advantage over a player that isn't buying microtransactions.", "appid": "960090", "steamid": "profiles/76561198006217347", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "10", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1589025600.0}
