{"text": "(Potential Spoilers from franchise) As a person who's played a lot of Telltale's titles, including the brilliant first and second season of this franchise, I'm disappointed. I had high expectations for this game after the finale of Season 2. Here's why I'm disappointed: - To begin with, the story about Javier felt irrelevant altogether, while I liked the character Javier himself, the rest of his family haven't got much to like about them. I didn't ever feel attached to any of the characters because they were written  in such a way that I couldn't do so. By that I mean, David acted like a jerk most of the time, Gabe was always trying to be someone he's not. I didn't like Kate being a romantic interest as it just felt a bit cliche for me. I wish the writing was better but it feels like a Soap Opera writer has written this with all the family issues that goes on during this season. - The episodes were way too short. I honestly enjoyed every minute of Season 1 and 2, and they were much longer. How is it a newer game has less content? The Part 1 and 2 episodes felt like 1 episode split in half but was less time than the other 3 episodes, almost like a cheesy way out of making an extra full length episode, why not just put them together so it's the same length as an episode from your AWARD WINNING TITLE Telltale The Walking Dead Season 1! - Choices. I know choices don't make a huge difference in Telltale's games, it only really has impacts on other characters opinions and decisions. To date, I still think one of the most interesting choices was the Carley/Doug choice from Season 1. Because one helped you gain \"Kenny points\" by telling him about your past, one did not. This overall had an interesting impact on Kenny's decisions later on. But I felt decisions in this game weren't exactly what people were expecting, for example, the decision where you end up telling David that \"Kate is thinking of leaving you\" even though that wasn't what you thought when you read that option. The writing there wasn't clear and I remember many people on the forums scratching their heads when this happened on the episodes release date. - References, I love references. I love characters remembering ones that are gone. Throw backs to old characters who are no longer with you gives me the feels. I love not forgetting them. This season had very little references to previous characters, in fact, I think only Lee and Kenny/Jane were mentioned at all. Which really dull writing, nothing to feel moved by. Season 2 was nice because you got to talk about previous characters with Alvin, Luke and Kenny and even got a really moving scene with Lee at the end of the season. But because Clementine wasn't the main character this season, they put very little in as Javier was a new face. Which brings me to my next point... - Why make a season which is technically season 3 designed for new players? I'm sorry, but if you are a new player to this franchise you should always start with the first game, especially if it's a story rich game. I don't think anyone asked for a game designed for new players. Clearly it didn't work anyway, many people have complained over the fact that Clementine isn't the main character. I hope Telltale realises that the vast majority of the people who played this game played the previous seasons.  - Good opportunity to use old characters or answer unanswered questions, but they don't. Would have been nice to see someone like Lily return this season, it would have made a lot of sense too, given the fact that she \"Wanted to stay put\" (New Frontier is a a camp), and that she has miltary experience which could have tied in with David. Would be been much better if we found out something about where Mike, Arvo and Bonnie (Determined) went or what happened in the end with Christa. I mean, Bonnie was written in the 400 Days DLC and goes with Tavia either way, because she was important to the story of Season 2, Christa spent more time with Clementine than Lee did (more months went by). It seems a shame that these characters were just thrown away and to not be used again to make a very interesting plot twist or shocking moment like when Kenny returned in Season 2 Episode 2. - The engine. The new engine somehow doesn't fit with the game's environment, I loved the engine on the first two games as it felt really comic book like. Now it feels a too much like a movie. I feel that the comic style type of engine was important to this franchise in particular since Robert Kirkman's The Walking Dead was and has always been a comic. To summarise, the writing wasn't good, there wasn't much of an interesting story, maybe a few OOO's and AHHHH's there, but definitely in no way lives up to it's previous titles, less content from a newer game. I'd get this game cheap or just not buy it at all and instead remember how good Season 1 and 2 were. {"text": "no more joke review >:( As one of their official Partnered Community Leaders, I was promised communication with the KurtzPel Team, and for the past few months that promise gradually began to fall through, and with it so did the morale of the other partners. The lack of transparency from the KurtzPel team for the past few months has taken a massive toll on this game, which you can evidently see on their official Discord and the current playercount. This game used to have around 3,000 concurrent players, and that number has steeped to a meager 1,000.  Overall tardiness to address issues and tardiness in issuing balance patches is a major factor to the resulting player count decline. They are willing to lose players because they want to save balance patches for a \"big update\" they have in store. This in hand means players will have to endure an entire month or two of repetitive gameplay that is plagued with poor balance and bugs. When the content update does come through, the \"balance\" changes generally lead to even more balance issues and thus, the cycle continues. The patch notes are released within a day before the actual patch, rendering player feedback for the new patch utterly useless as players do not have any intervention between these updates. There was once a period of time where they had a testing server which greatly alleviated some issues for a time, but the discontinuation of it has once again stirred more issues then it has fixed as the lack of community feedback intervention between updates for 2 months has shown to be quite detrimental to the game's health. In terms of actual gameplay and its surrounding aspects, issues that have plagued the game since launch still exist to this day. Noticeable server lag for the Asia and Europe regions. Simple bugs that were reported on day one that are still not fixed today. Unfair matchmaking and wintrading issues are still prominent. Game optimization has only gotten worse, with the addition of an unasked for server lobby changes that allows 50 more players in the lobby. Overall game rewards have declined immensely. The first Pre-Season awarded players with a variety of the game's lootboxes, dyes, and exclusive golden accessories as well as the usual in-game currency rewards (CP). The current Pre-Season right now only offers CP with no other incentives. For event rewards, for the past 2 months players were given Basic Boxes for staying logged in for 30 minutes, and the boxes for the majority of the time gave useless rewards and the infamous Basic Dye, which is roughly 3 cents. Even the current Christmas Event has rewards locked by a lootbox that functions very similar to the Basic Box, meaning players will generally get poor rewards and will most likely not be able to get most of the event exclusive items that may never return. They are hesitant to give formal responses to lingering and prominent issues of the game. Before players were given lengthy responses to the future and current state of the game, but now this game undergoes periods of times where you can do nothing but wait for the next update that hopefully fixes issues. For instance, a 20 minute PvE cooldown for all missions was initiated because the team thought there was an exploit that allowed unusually fast clears. Now, the PvE cooldown has been reduced to 10 minutes and no further explanation or follow up was given afterwards. It is very disheartening to see the game at a state like this, and the game's Early Access ends in 2020 as per their statement which you can see on the store page. Please know that I have no hard feelings against the company or their team members. But if there's anything I could want right now, I would want to come back to a game that properly acknowledges their community and listens to them.", "appid": "844870", "steamid": "profiles/76561198067940958", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "12", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1556625600.0}

{"text": "Ever since i was in my early teens i always admired MMORPGs and wanted to try out...all of them pretty much, or if nothing, at least the most famous ones. Aion was surely on that list, as i heard a lot of things about it, but i never managed to play it until certain 5.0 patch part, few months before 6.0, and it somehow remained on the end of my list. Then, it seemed like somewhat casual MMORPG, with a lot of quests, but it also felt like it was missing a lot of interesting PvE things and exploring. Still, in that 5.0 patch i managed to have some fun, and there were quests to do, even if it didnt seem like most interesting game ever. I played up to level 12 or something, and it took me like 2 hours or so back then, since there was a lot of quests. I quit it so i can play something else, since person i played with wasnt that interested and thought i might come back later a bit. Few months later 6.0 arrived, and i decided to try the AION again, more seriously this time, from the start with new character. The classes didnt change, there are still 6 basic classes which evolve into one of 2 paths you must choose at level 10, 11 of them, considering bard class has only one path. Leveling became extremely fast now, you could get to level 10 under 30 minutes, everything was sped up and parts of map were cut off. Choosing the path is bad as it used to be, you get no introduction to your skills during those first 10 levels, rather you simply have to make a random choice. After picking the path for my class, one of the worst experiences in MMORPGs began. The quests in this game are so extremely linear and with 6.0 update every possible quest that could've been cut off to speed up the leveling has been cut off. You will find only few 2-3 side quests in each village and continue off with main quest. However these main quests had such ridiculous design where you'd have to enter a solo dungeon which is played for over an hour and you get a new one every 5-10 levels. While most MMORPGs offer you rewards to improve your weapon and interesting side quests, leveling in 6.0 system made me feel like someone was constantly pushing me from my back to level up as soon as possible, not to enjoy the game, but rather to become another server slot filler in it. I've barely seen 5 different players as i was leveling up. Maps looked somewhat interesting but game doesnt offer any quests that take you on a nice tour to explain it, rather tedious quests that focus on one small part of the map. This keeps getting worse, not only since for rewards you get only equipment on every 10 levels, but because game forces you to go through dozens of mobs (which take extremely long time to kill), and the useless wings you have can only be used on very rare special parts of the map where you can fly. I reached level 56 and i still havent seen a single mount in this game, and maps are quite large to walk all the time. The game offers you one option though, which is to drink \"Transformation potion\" which gives you huge boost but at same time turns you at weird looking furry monster or undead skeleton, depending on the potion (good job spending all the time making your character). These potions have legendary versions which offer boosts like +40% speed +35% attack +15% attack speed and much more with different buff combinations which are HUGE buffs and will make you even twice as strong. These potions are of course, very expensive as well , and have cash shop option for purchase. I've reached level 56 somehow through sheer curiosity and test to my endurance i suppose, and i really cant see myself playing much more, maybe in instances of 20 minutes and playing on and off, just so i could see how alive the endgame is, and that is if there really isnt anything else to play. Even the towns are so extremely filled with so many useless NPCs that have names above them to give you a fake illusion of other players being there. Whatever Aion used to be, it surely isnt this game. This is an attempt to make a very blatant cash cow game, and while there are many of those games, they at least try to cover it up and sometimes offer fun events and rewards for players.", "appid": "261430", "steamid": "profiles/76561198121525707", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "3", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1540641600.0}

{"text": "\"Its not what it looks like\" The main moto of any review you`ll see, positive or negative. I and many other horror-lovers wanted to see vibrant colorful hell, full of blood, pain and terror. We got VERY dark walking sim with kinda questionable stealth and IMO lazy done text collectibles. I wont go deep in what went wrong, just what I personally wanted and will buy this game when it will be done: 1. Remove that damn darkness everywhere, hell is not dark, its full of red, purple and yellow, full of fires, burning souls, flesh. Whats the point in walking 50% of time in complete darkness? I mean it, completely remove stealth based on darkness, its plain stupid. If levels will become empty caves, so be it! {"text": "Updated review after over 100 hours of play... Had to change from a slightly positive thumbs up to a mostly negative thumbs down mainly because the balancing is buggered, the PIR system doesn't work at all, you can have 2 cars with the same PIR rating and be over 2 seconds a lap faster in 1 car and 2 seconds off in the other (yes i am taking in to account the right type of car for the circuit and taking in to account the car's stats shown in game). Online consists of 3 things: Quick play which is the best of the 3 dumping you in to 1 of a pool of track/car combinations but you're lucky to get more than 1 other player in a typical quick play session Scheduled events which expose how broken the PIR system really is, the winner is always the person with the fastest car even though the PIR is supposed to provide balanced classes for racing but the PIR number 9/10 times means absolutely nothing, your 499PIR rated category A supercar in a 500 PIR limited race will likely lose to 499 PIR sh*tbox with upgrades from category C. Also has too many laps for too little reward (will talk more about the payout rate in a moment). Lastly you have Custom lobbies, at peak times you find up to a dozen lobbies to choose from and the majority of the time you are lucky to have 2 to choose from, i would say i get 1 decent race in these lobbies out of every 20. If you win a race, drive cleanly on an average online race (3x laps) you get 7k XP (without bonuses if you get any and at max with bonuses you are looking at 50k XP,) and even if you win a scheduled event which are the longest races which can last up to 30 minutes don't pay out much more, considering the money you earn is tied to the XP system (around 70k XP to fill the bar to get any payout takes from 15k to 30k depending on your driver level) it really leaves you feeling like you aren't being rewarded for your wins or the effort you put in to a race. Offline isn't much better either although at least you get bigger payouts after championships but they only payout once so no grinding a single event for cash which really annoys me. I don't think i've ever felt so torn about a racing game in my 20 years in the genre, i stand by my original statement in the 1st version of this review, it has a good foundation for a simcade but the balancing is nowhere near good enough to provide close racing without having to resort to forcing everyone in to identical cars with default setups, that may not sound shocking but that narrows the possibilities severely, resulting in online play that is either mixed racing were the fastest car will win by seconds per lap even thought it claims via the PIR system that the cars are balanced and competitive but aren't at all, or you have tryhards running lobbies with a specific car they own then forcing everyone else to use it except the owner's car is tuned for the circuit and/or has performance upgrades to provide an advantage over people using standard borrowed cars. Not even going to go in to the exploits being used on specific circuits which allow you to cut chicane sections without any penalties which can save 5 to 10 seconds per lap (found this out on a scheduled event when i was leading the race and 2nd and 3rd caught up then passed by using this exploit, had to do it myself to regain the win, yes i felt dirty afterwards :/). Also since the first/last patch the game keeps crashing when it was stable before that (bug filled but stable), now it is unstable and still has too many bugs. The physics are pretty good, decent for drifting fun in a solo lobby because you try to find anybody to drift with in this game, tis hard, even more so than PC2, and that was very hard indeed to find a tandem partner online. Overall, don't buy it, SMS, what is going on over there? What happened to you? {"text": "æ²¡æœ‰æ— æŸï¼Œåªæœ‰MP3", "appid": "1245180", "steamid": "profiles/76561198166453682", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1594814400.0}
{"text": "Amazing atmosphere, both in the way of graphical and sound design. Multiplayer gameplay, though not very varied or tactically deep, is somewhat enjoyable much in the same way as other horde shooters, such as Left 4 Dead or Payday are. The selection of weapons is adequate, if still somewhat small, and is further narrowed down by the obvious underpoweredness of some and clear superiority of other weapons. There is little room for improvement here, though, as the only Terminator-grade weapon from WH40K that is not in the game are the Chainfist Gauntlets. Enemies come in a greater variety, and have different strengths and weaknesses, which requires some strategic thinking both on the level of individual players, and the team as a whole. Objectives are greatly varied. Singleplayer is simply trash, without most of these positive qualities. In multiplayer, judicious amount of sheer bullsh*t, such as somwhat tanky, fast, and almost completely invisible enemies that can one or two hit kill you and come in groups, psykers that can oneshot kill you with a hitscan attack from a hundred meter away, heavy stubbers (the WH40K equivalent of an airsoft rifle) destroying your Terminator armor with 5-6 shots, or RNG-driven \"critical hits\" that cannot be parried and will wound or kill you no matter what are something that you will have to put up with if you wish to play on higher difficulties, which is necessary to gain any meaningful amount of XP and unlock customizations and upgrades at a bearable rate. Good situational awareness can negate these threats most of the time, but death still comes, often, and suddenly, be prepared that this game is not a power fantasy. Unfortunately, Space Hulk Deathwing is clearly unfinished, even with the Enchanted Edition, the UI is laughably unpolished and the game is infested with bugs (and I do not mean the genestealers), but to be fair, most outright gamebreaking ones are fixed. The netcode is a whole different story though, it is highly unstable, and will likely give you massive lagspikes (freezes) and hit detection issues, if not just throw you off of whichever server you are playing on right away.   There is no mod support in the game. No multiplayer bots, so you either get people to join your server, or you will be playing alone. No voice chat. Very barebones radial command menu. Barely functional server browser. You get the point, core functionality is either outright missing, or just implemented in a half-arsed way. Non-core, \"quality of life\" functionality is unheard of.  Adding insult to the inury, the developers declared that they are done with the game, and since the release of the Enhanced Edition, there is no official support of any kind to speak of, and they have completely abandoned the game and its community. Regardless, even in this state, Deathwing is an OK horde shooter carried to the occasional moments of glory by its setting in the 40K universe, and indeed, it is the best WH40K themed shooter at the moment. Due to its great many flaws, and the audacity of the developers to flip off the community in such a way, I cannot recommend it at a full price, however, if it's on a discount, say, -50% at least, consider grabbing it.", "appid": "816090", "steamid": "profiles/76561198035535447", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1579867200.0}

{"text": "An endless typing game featuring Valiant Knights characters. Or at least, I don't think it has an ending as I played to round 500. You fight monsters by typing words on one of the 3 characters on the screen, and the damage depends on the type of the attack magic versus the monster's affinity, which is convenient shown on the top right corner. For every 4 levels, there will be a boss monster, which will deal more damage to you, but is not necessarily tougher than regular mob monsters. As you defeat monsters, you will gain level at the rate of around 3 round per 1 level (and the rate doesn't slow down even when you level up), which will persist to the next run. At the beginning, you will die quite a bit, but as you level up, the first few level becomes extremely boring as the monsters can be defeated in one hit, and the fade out between levels is longer than the time you need to finish it. {"text": "As an Assassin's Creed fanboi, for many years i wondered if i should give a try to Chronicles, since they are not included in the saga history. So far, i'm not enjoying Chronicles China. Chronicles China gives you the history of Shao Jun, the Chinese assassin, Ezio meets on Assassin's Creed Embers. Shao is fighting against the templars of China in order to seek vengeance of the fallen Chinese brotherhood. I like the way they tell Shao Jun's journey with small interactive drawings and amazing art behind them, but the main problem with this game, starts right in the story telling, the accent. HOW IN THE HELL, a game, set on china, has actors that speak American English? is cringe, and breaks the immersion. This happened on Unity, and it happened in here aswell. Worse than that? is probably the mechanics they implemented on this game. Gameplay is completly destroyed by the horrendous controls... Most of your actions work by using 2 buttons at the same time, for example: - Throwing a knife, you need to press (F + G) and that is extremely unconfortable. Most of your actions that not running, crouching or climbing, are like that. - Blocking an attack ( D + C or A + C), now imagine doing that... - Blocking and rolling to the enemies back (D+C+SPACE) how in the hell i m going to do that? Last but not least, many times i witnessed, that Shao Jun doesn't react when pressing a button. There was times, i was behind an enemy, pressing \"Mouse\" in order to assassinate, and she simply doesn't react. {"text": "Disclaimer: I RECOMMEND you buy this game on sale, not full price. This game can be fun, but it's unpolished and has tons of issues.. I haven't found a proper balance- Rookie is so damn easy that you can easily drop 60+ points 10+ rebs, asts, and steals (per game),  and WIN almost every single game. The AI of your team also seems to be fairly on point. Pro is basically the same- it's slightly more difficult, but it's still really easy. Then, All-Star is more reasonable, but it's still not easy. Actually being able to steal the basketball, being able to pass it without getting a turnover, and making shots more than missing becomes a somewhat rare occurence.  Your team AI becomes worse, and the opposing team's AI improves. Superstar is more of the same, however making shots becomes even more difficult, and your team AI becomes garbage, whilst the opposing team plays top-notch. Attempting to steal the ball will most of the time lead to a reach-in foul. Turnovers become extremely prevalent in this difficulty, as it seems the opposing team intercepts 50 percent of your passes. But, although I have bashed these difficulties, it still is very possible to win, it's just most games will be a nail-biter.  Also, it will likely be not very fun, as you will miss shots way more often, get fouls way more easily, and accumulate turnovers at a ridiculous rate. But, the Hall of Fame difficulty is the real problem with this game. Shots simply don't go in for you or your team anymore; you'll be lucky to make 20 percent of your threes. Steals simply won't happen for you (be prepared to get fouled out), or your team anymore (probably for the other team though). Turnovers will make up a big part of your stats....and you simply will not have fun at this point. It's very unlikely you will win at this difficulty unless you are very skilled. You essentially have to do everything yourself, as your team becomes useless, while the opposing team excels.  The whole difficulty curve thing is just ONE issue with this game. It is so unpolished, with voice actor messups included in the game, pointless and boring cutscenes, repetitive dialogue, server issues, and an insane amount of hackers within those servers.. If you want to have fun, and you aren't that good, play rookie/pro. It's easy, but at least it's actually enjoyable. HoF is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, Superstar is stressful, and All-Star MIGHT be okay (I don't remember this one too well. I just know as the difficulty increases, it generally just becomes even less fun. I don't recall a huge difference between All-Star and Superstar). I just feel as if they release these games without even â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ thinking. There are so many transparent issues with this game... that it's just absurd. Every aspect of this game seems to have some abnormality that ruins it in some way.  I would buy this game on sale, maybe, but definitely not for full price. The online mode is pretty bad- it's filled with hackers, and it's definitely not noob friendly( I lost most of the time). It also has a host of server issues. This game in general is unpolished, and the difficulty curve is just straight-up dumb. I'll give this game a 5/10, but I'm gonna put this as not recommended. There's too many issues that can only be overlooked under a cheaper pricetag. P.S. I wrote this when I was worse at the game, and thus this made my review a tad more negative. The difficulties above All-Star are pretty ridiculous, but All-Star is relatively reasonable and not overly arduous after playing for a while. This game truly is a grind, it's unpolished, but it's very fun, and basically a necessity if you are a big NBA fan. Once again however, ONLY buy it on sale. TLDR; Buy on sale. Game is a massive grindfest, really unpolished, and flawed in so many ways, but it can be incredibly fun. {"text": "Update: Gonna thumbs down this one. Somehow my saves got erased and my game doesn't go past the intro. So yeah â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you telltale. As I'm a hardcore fan of Telltale games, thought of giving a review for the first episode. Note that this review isn't biased to the dev.  Since I'm a big GoT fan , instantly got this, was not worried at all about the story and the decisions. The story is in parallel with the tv show especially , since the characters, voice acting and some elements of the story are alike. You represent House Forrester, atleast to a certain degree and you won't be confined to one character like in TWD or TWAU. This is somewhat similar to 'The tales from the Borderlands' as the story is given from multiple perspectives. It's a good take by Telltale games imo especially since you know the gravity of your decisions and how they'd affect you as another character. Moving on to the plot. The story so far , atleast in the first episode was top notch and I got to say I was pretty skeptical about the game after seeing how Polygon gave it a 6.5. But just for now the story has been great. The way it shows how major effects of the book/show affect minor houses is brilliantly executed.  The decisions are playing a major role like they've played in the previous Telltale games. But this time around like Totalbiscuit said, it's solely not emphasizing on dialogues and etc, but rather small ones like \"taking this\" or \"not taking this\". The weight of your decisions are felt by your own playable characters as they have to go through them. This game thus far have been the best Telltale game with hard decisions for me. It's not only that, they manage completely to nail the grim nature of of GoT. This game isn't rated R, it doen't certainly have boobies, but holy cow it's violent. In a good way which is what Game of Thrones is all about. Moving on the the gameplay, the devs have used the same gameplay elements they have used in previous games, if you are looking for a button smashing, sword blazing GoT, THIS ISN'T THE GAME FOR YOU. Point and click mechanics and quick times events have been in the game so far with nothing new gameplay wise. The voice acting was excellent, especially since they were done by some of the original cast. Not to mention some of the scores from the original series. However the only thing I have against this game is the new graphics they have used. It doesn't look bad, but it seems a bit muddy and unpolished in a way. At times you can see some of the textures blur for no reason, that's something Telltale should work on. And the weird animations of characters can get clunky at times. Improvement from these two departments would have made this game a much better experience for consumers. But then again no one plays Telltale games for graphics. Overall this game is pretty damn good. You should note, if you haven't seen the TV show nor read the books, be sure to do either of them. Because this game is heavily based on the what has already happened in the series so far. Hopefully Telltale would release other episodes rather quickly than what they did with TWUA but for now if you already have the game, you'll be playing it a multiple times to see what could have been if you had taken another choice. I'd give it a solid 9/10. However this may change with the coming episodes. For now it's an excellent game. A MUST BUY FOR GAME OF THRONES AND TELLTALE FANS!", "appid": "330840", "steamid": "profiles/76561198068882850", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1417608000.0}

{"text": "This game is a frankenstein abomination of different Sonic games and really has no business being called Sonic 4. If you're looking for a good Sonic game to play or a new 2D platformer, skip this one and head straight for Episode 2.   is a much better game. If you're looking for a good nostalgia trip, grab Sonic Generations. If you're still on the fence about this one, read on. Sonic 4 Episode 1 is the first part of an episodic approach to returning to Sonic the Hedgehog's roots, riding the 2D revival bandwagon started by games like New Super Mario Bros. There is nothing wrong with the idea, but Sega put absolutely no effort into preserving their most important mascot's heritage. Sonic 4 was outsourced to Dimps, which makes its complete failure even more baffling, as Dimps has made several decent to good handheld Sonic games over the years.  They must have let the janitorial staff take over for this project, because it's clear no one understood what makes a good game, let alone a good Sonic game. The graphics are garish with a prerendered art style that isn't evocative of any Sonic game except maybe 3D Blast (which no one wanted to be reminded of). The music sounds like it's coming out of a bootleg Genesis/Megadrive; the compositions aren't necessarily bad, but the sound is very unappealing. The level design is bottom-tier Sonic but still modeled after actual Sonic games, but the borked physics result in bizarre situations like Sonic moonwalking in slowmotion on a ceiling, or just stopping on a dime. For a game called Sonic 4, it takes several steps back and uses its predecessors as crutches. As such, its truncated level selection gives us such wonderful, original zones as   Splash Hill Zone, Casino   Street Zone,   Labyrinth Zone,   Mad Gear Zone, and   EGG Station Zone. So to sum it up, we have an inferior rehash with half the content of a typical Sonic game due to its episodic nature. Someone at Sega must have wised up because Episode 2 is such a big step up over this and I can't recommend someone put up with it when you can get far better Sonic experiences on Steam.", "appid": "202530", "steamid": "profiles/76561198038079261", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1411992000.0}

{"text": "Ð¸Ð³Ñ€Ð° ÑÐ°Ð¼Ð° Ð½Ðµ Ð¿Ð»Ð¾Ñ…Ð°Ñ Ð½Ð¾ Ð¸Ð³Ñ€Ð¾ÐºÐ¸ ÑÑ‚Ð¾ Ñ‚ÑƒÐ¿Ñ‹Ðµ Ð¸ Ð´Ð¸Ð¾Ñ‚Ñ‹ ÐºÐ¾Ñ‚Ñ‹Ñ€Ñ‹Ðµ ÑƒÐ±ÑŒÑŽÑ‚ Ñ‚ÐµÐ±Ñ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¾ÑÑ‚Ð¾ Ñ‚Ð°Ðº", "appid": "945360", "steamid": "profiles/76561198439018709", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": 0, "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1601899200.0}
{"text": "First thing's first, I am an avid lover of the MGS franchise for a long time, I got into it fairly late at Metal Gear Solid 3: Subsistance's launch. Since that time I've scoured the earth looking for everything Metal Gear as I quickly fell in love with it. I've purchased most of the titles \" save acid because â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ that game \" more than once, this includes the Legacy Collection, and haven't regretted it. I love this series and I absolutely love supporting it. Now onto the nitty gritty.  Let's get one thing straight right now, I absolutely LOVE playing this game. It's all the adrenaline filled action and stealth based infiltration that I've come to know, love, and expect from the Metal Gear name. It has everything that I've ever wondered, \" what if \" from other Metal Gear titles, and the Fox Engine is superb. The game runs well \" at least on my system \" and the only crash I've ever had can simply be attributed to drivers or ugh....skype. Unfortunately, that's where the good things come to a screeching, violent, rage-induced halt.  MGSV brings TOO many things from Peace Walker, other than Peace Walker's co op ( Which BTW wasn't added in this game for some â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ reason ) people hated that game. You couldn't crawl ( you literally were only allowed to sit still while prone ) the boss fights were just â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing tanks and apc's essentially ( something MGSV also LOVES doing for some â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing reason ). The amount of supplies snake has at his disposal is directly related to how well researched in those areas you are. This means that you have to focus on resource and staff management in order to better equip yourself for missions. While this can add game time it does very little to add any actual depth to the weapons and items you are using as most of the upgrades boil down to, \" More Damage, higher accuracy at range, more ammo, wider explosive radius, new attachments \". While getting these upgrades is nice, there's no satisfaction from it, as the upgrades are SO small, that you end up not noticing anything that isn't a max ammo increase or a new sight on your gun. The tranq upgrades are HORRIBLE and it becomes NEARLY useless around 55% of the way through the main campaign ( which btw is only 50 missions long and most of these are copy paste objectives from EARLIER missions. In other words, BUSY WORK ...more on that in a bit. ) because it cannot penetrate armor. This means that if you aim at someone's head who's wearing LITERALLY the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ helmet in the game that might as well be your grandmother's cooking pot, it won't even knock it off. You MUST shoot them SPECIFICALLY in the mouth or chin, or it counts as hitting the helmet or the kevlar vest, both of which are a no no.  The weapon customization options are pitiful when you finally do unlock them, and most changes to the guns don't ACTUALLY do ANYTHING. I've literally found around three parts that make changes to the base gun model. It's good for nothing more than painting your guns or adding flashlights though god only knows why the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you'd bother with those.  Weapons are weak, uninspired \" this is an ak but we can't call it that \" generic trash, that all feel the exact same. It feels as though there's no REAL force behind any of the guns so you end up just blazing into an enemy as they do the mafia movie cliche' \" riddled with bullets \" dance while you tear at them. Headshots are effective as always in a MGS game however once they acquire the first class of helmets you are forced to shoot them in the mouth as I said earlier, even the second highest penetration sniper rifle requires two shots through the first helmet, which makes a certain someone useless. Armor completely negates EVERYTHING you do in this game save CQC, which throws even putting people to sleep at range out the window as late game enemies are LITERALLY covered head to toe in armor, even the back of their arms and legs,not kidding.   The \" vast open world \" we were shown and told about amounts to little more than a New Vegas - esque lane outpost to outpost layout. It's literally Far Cry 2 with even LESS areas to explore. You will find yourself mind numbingly stumbling through the game later on taking down hostiles and picking up resources just because you've gotten to a point where you're going through the motions, the areas are totally uninspired, even if they are gorgeous to look at. You do openly have the freedom to approach missions in almost anyway you want, I say almost because as I said earlier armor completely invalidates ranged stealth takedowns, and the terain for the most part supports it. That is, whenever snake isn't randomly sliding down inclines that I could easily crawl up myself. Snake has the ability to traverse almost any kind of terrain fairly easily, however there are some inclines that make traversal INFURIATING, there's a specific spot in mind when I write this that got me caught multiple times, because you can't tell that it's impossible to go up the hill from a distance, you can't crawl up it, you can't crouch walk up it, you can't SPRINT up it, and how steep is this incline you ask? Let me put it this way, I could sit on it without any danger of falling.  After having beaten the game, I can tell you the story is a complete â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ pot of terrible writing. I don't know what the hell got into their heads but THIS is Metal Gear's Swan Song? This game has amazing sound design, fun, tight, responsive gameplay, and oozes with atmosphere, but the story? 70% of it is in audio tapes that you have to listen to manually because the game developers for some stupid reason were too lazy to give you a \" listen to tape now \" button. There's SO many shortcomings in this game that I have the feeling that they just threw â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ in here to slap an MG title on it. The whole \" twist \" at the ending of the game is about as subtle as a freight train derailing and smashing into a chemical plant. The Stealth Skulls are LITERALLY flawless in the way they are designed, if you fire ONE round while in their FOV they all look at you and begin firing. Also, microtransactions on the online. Just boring and without any kind of entertainment or replayability value since it's all about clicking and buying images of things. {"text": "On paper (apt, given its origin), sounds great - party-based CRPG plus kingdom management. What could go wrong? As it turns out, a few things. Combat is not enjoyable at all, and there's a hell of a lot of it. The difficulty spikes have been pointed out in other reviews, and I can only echo them. It is not helped by the way that characters start off overloaded with abilities; when combined with the difficulty and limited party AI, the micromanagement involved causes combat to drag on interminably. Kingdom management is even less enjoyable. It's built around a quite specific meta - fail to make certain choices (including, unforgivably, story choices) and progress in a certain manner, and you'll be beset by problems. As much as I hated making story choices to suit kingdom management, the pile of inaccessible options without those choices was even more infuriating. Even then it's replete with frustrations, and you can't delegate to the AI because it's dreadful in this respect. The sad thing is that I actually enjoyed the writing enough to try to push through. Some of the characters are endearing, and I found some of the side quests engrossing (the main quest not so much). Even then, I couldn't bring myself to finish the game - the final quest seemed to drag on forever, and it got to the point where I couldn't force myself ahead any more.  Sidenote, the magical lantern mechanic is the absolute pits. Apparently there's a sequel coming; even if it improves the combat and kingdom management, I'm not going anywhere near it if the accursed lantern is back.", "appid": "640820", "steamid": "profiles/76561198003132759", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1594382400.0}

{"text": "i have only played this game for about fifteen minutes, but a quarter of an hour is all it will take for you to have seen everything this game has to offer. As you might have guessed from the screenshots, this is pretty much a Flash game. It may not be coded in Flash, but it is very much of the low-quality that one might expect from any of the thousands of free-to-play, web-based, simple mouse + keyboard games found on sites like NewGrounds. Which brings us to the first problem with this game. It really should be controllable with a standard twin-stick controller, which it is not. Using the steam controller is relatively painless, once you have managed to get the damned thing set-up properly which brings us to issues number two and three. This game really does not like you reconfiguring the Steam Controller while it is running. I managed to set up a working configuration, but I had to reset my machine a couple of times in the process as changing the config. caused my Steam Machine to get stuck on the configuration editor screen. And the game is just really poorly coded in general, really amateurish in almost every aspect, even for a gag-game. How a game of this quality makes it to the Steam Store is a mystery. Except when one considers the marketing value of using a well known meme as your premise. So if this is some kind of cynical marketing excercise by valve then \"Boo Valve!\" Which brings us to my more subjective criticisms of this game. Being meme-based is not necessarily a bad thing in itself, but this game gives me the distinct impression that the author spent about as much time working on this game as one might typically spend on producing one of the simple comic strip images which this game is based on. I would be surprised and a little disappointed if the author spent any longer than 15 minutes to half an hour working on this. That kind of production quality might be fine for what basically amounts to free content on a social media platform, and might be a laugh if played for free on the afore mentioned website NewGrounds. But this is Steam, and even for two US quarters this games is overpriced by at least 100% . Even if you have several gigabytes of rage meme images on your hard-disk I might still advise against purchasing this game, the only enjoyment I see myself getting out of this game is the small amount of joy I get from identifying bugs and then laying the boot into a poor game. 2.5 out of 10", "appid": "554310", "steamid": "profiles/76561198333010227", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "16", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1491048000.0}

{"text": "Let me start this review by saying, that this is not a bad game and you should consider giving it a go, you can always refund if it does not tickle your fancy. Please keep in mind, I am not a pro at shmups, but I am good enough to usually get half the game on first run. That being said, gameplaywise Shikhondo is a generic bullet hell game with graze mechanic that charges a flash bomb. As many others I was drawn in by the visual design and music. The visual design in particular is really detailed and unique, music is ok, I bought it with soundtrack but unlike other shmups I played nothing was memorable. So now for the major problems I had: * The game looks amazing, but as a result it has also some 'loading times'. In other games loading usually is either instant or so short you do not notice. In case of Shikhondo it is really noticeable as it can take between +5 to +10 seconds (tested on lowest and highest graphical settings). * There is no death bombing - it has become sort of a standard in modern shmups, and it is really noticeable when you try to react to something you cannot dodge, it's a simple thing but would make life a lot easier. In conclusion: Shikhondo in my personal opinion is just generic, aside from visual design nothing really stands out compared to other titles which are available on steam for similar price. It is worth checking out, but if you have some experience and a library of other shmups you might be disappointed.", "appid": "720150", "steamid": "profiles/76561198038121294", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "1", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1562932800.0}

{"text": "If you are a Star Wars fan and looking for some new and engaging Star Wars stories, then this is the game for you. Star Wars the Old Republic is full of phenomenal class campaigns, with eight in total and hours of playtime in store for each of them however it unfortunately fails as an MMORPG. If you are not a Star Wars fan and are instead looking for a new MMORPG to invest yourself in, then I can't recommend this game. SWTOR is best described as an mmoRPG, with a major emphasis on the RPG while the MMO elements are lacking. The reason this game failed after launch and died was due to it being herald as the WoW Killer which of course, it never lived up to as the PvE and PvP elements of the game were lackluster and the end game was pretty bad. I do highly regret pre-purchasing the Collector's Edition of this game but I at least found some fun in leveling my first few characters. As for the expansions, I've heard they've gotten better overtime but I have only played the first one, which was total â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. The game has also aged pretty badly, especially in the graphics department but the story is still great and worthwhile. I just hope that this game's failure discourages future Star Wars MMORPGs as this game had a LOT of potential. Or Iâ€™ll have a data retrieval mission against the Eldar, and the instant they get the data from me they take off across the map 200% faster than any ship of mine on full burn. Itâ€™s ridiculous. It makes the game no fun at all, and I cannot recommend it as such. For example, I kept beating my head against an Ork blockade or \"Breakthrough\" mission. Your objective is to destroy two small defense platforms. The problem is that you're limited to 300 points of ships, and that means at best you take a big cruiser, a light cruiser, and an escort, or you can manage two light cruisers and a couple escorts. The Orks were consistently fielding 2 full cruisers, 4 light cruisers, and 4 escorts. I couldn't even get near the stations. Until about my 20th-plus attempt, when a bizarre quirk of the random generator that sets up the missions put the Orks in a bad starting location. I set my engines to full burn, did a drive by on both stations, and blew them to bits. The objective box ticked, and I smiled as I told my fleet to warp out. Some folks say you can win only by blowing everything up, others say you can win if you make it to the other end of the map, and others agree with me that it's impossible. Whatever the case, I'm done wasting my time on a game that just isn't fun anymore. {"text": "Right. Where do I begin.. I somehow managed to 100% this game. I regret it. At first, the game seemed to be okay. It was a relaxing little game where you were swimming under water, collecting treasure and catching fish with a harpoongun. It was only later I discovered its dark, dark intentions. +PROS+ +Some of the 3D models look okay. +The music is okay, but nothing special. -CONS- -The textures are.. It's just plain ugly. -A crab poses a much larger threat than a shark. -A very, very bad treasure hunting mission that can be very hard to do if you don't have a hawks' eyes. -Very short game. -You cannot replay the missions. The only way to replay a mission is to go into the game files on your computer and delete them. -Only 3 maps. -Small maps. You are constantly reminded that ''You cannot leave this area''. -Collecting treasure is WAY less beneficial than catching fish. You almost feel punished for collecting treasures. -Can cause motion sickness. Right, let's get to my biggest complaint. I love to hunt achievements, and this game wasn't gonna be an exception. It started off okay. Collect some treasures, catch alot of fish, travel some great distances, take alot of photos. When I had beaten the game and gone out of my way to get a few, I was only missing one achievement. 'Captain Nemo'. This is the worst designed achievement I've ever come across. The game tracks how many SECONDS you spend under water in the game. You get the achievement once you've spent 86,400 seconds under water. Also known as 24 hours. This wouldn't have been so bad if there was ANYTHING to do once you beat the game. You can't even go back and replay missions. There is seriously nothing for you to do besides just swimming around, so you just have to idle the last 20 hours. But that is where the real problems start. First of all, you can't alt tab. Doing so will pause the game and the seconds will no longer be counted. Secondly, if you purchase the full lungs upgrade, you can be under water for a total of 15 minutes before you have to go back up to the surface to catch air. If your oxygen goes to 0%, you go back to the title screen. So what you are left with is that you have to sit in front of your computer with the game running, and swim to the surface every 14ish minutes for 20 hours. It was the most boring evening of my life. I did read up on some exploits that froze time ingame, but it didn't work for me. Nor does it fix the problem of the game having to be open the entire time. By the time you are reading this review, the game is long gone from my hard drive and I am most likely getting treatment for PTSD.", "appid": "248530", "steamid": "profiles/76561198043555854", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "23", "votes_funny": "18", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1516622400.0}

{"text": "The game is super unpolished, and the boss fights are nowhere near the older games fun level. Classic mode is a requirement for any enjoyment, while dodge to win mechanics are pure cheese that are laughable compared to the advanced capabilities of the older titles. The movement speed is also unbearably slow compared to horse riding on the older games, and the lack of map feature makes backtracking for items annoying and requires alt-tabbing for walkthroughs. Any movement in general is bad, and there is a lot of platforming with bad movement. Including the flaky whip pipe to move mechanic, and jump to ledge with subpar jumping ability. (you'll know if you play it, as you can only just barely make it, and have to climb up every time.) Killing the horse reminds me of Starwars killing off Han and Luke, and makes me wonder if the devs are pulling a Starwars or SpecOps mind game on us. Like they deliberately wanted to make a bad game because they secretly hate the fans or something.  I dislike the crucible too, but the game needs some better items to be tolerable, and after grinding for those items and power leveling, you can become OP enough that the normal game feels stupid. The game doesn't give you enough normal weapon upgrades on purpose, weapons aren't equally balanced, and switching modes is janky. It would be ideal if I could double tap to fire jump then storm coast down, but you can't. There is no balance or polish with this game. It is designed to be either frustrating or stupid easy. There is no fun normal gameplay, and the puzzle mechanics are just as unpolished and unintuitive. I have multiple playthroughs of Darksiders 2, which may even increase later on. Meanwhile, Darksiders 3 is getting ONE, and I will never play it again unless it gets a map and better balancing. Also, throw some damn hints around for some of the puzzles. They're not all intuitive. Anyways, Darksiders 3 is a good way to kill a franchise. If it isn't dead already, and I hear any rumors that 4 is just as bad, it will not get a purchase until it goes on sale cheap. DS3 is just pure trolling that is only worth playing for the story, since the game itself is terrible. Even if they were going for Dark Souls, it wasn't done right. None of the mechanics are even close to Souls polish and balancing. Including slow loading the game to a checkpoint after death, when the damn game should be in memory, and instant load. PS. {"text": "Door to Door is somewhat of a detective exploration game but lesser. You play as Bixby, an agent of the Ministry of Order. You basically go around the city investigating crimes (not really). The truth is, you follow clues and just interact with them. You don't need to think most of the time, just walk around wishing that you get to your objective because you just want to get it over with. The world is boring and lifeless. It is a world governed by robots and I find no humans or anything like that (well I didn't really play till the end cause it was killing me, honestly.)  I hate giving bad reviews to games because I know the developers worked hard on it but this one is not really a \"full game\" in my opinion. It lacks flavor, colors, and fun. The world is bland and big, you spend most of the time wandering it and you'll get bored. There are no subtitles in the game and I read a post by the developer that there will be no subtitles coming anytime soon (I think its because of the engine or something). There is also no way to review clues, when you press ESC you just have the options to go to settings or quit the game. The inability to review clues bothers me so much. I mean, its tagged as detective but you can't review your case files. If this game is on early access, I may have followed it because the concept is nice. The graphics is a great (it is basically the best thing in the game). But Door to Door is not on early access and it still feels incomplete. Additionally, I think the price is too high for this game. The characters are alright but there are so few. You have yourself, your assistant, charizmo (he's the guy to ask for directions), and depending on the case you are currently on, some few more characters. It would have been great if there were a bunch of characters in the background. I mean there is a bar, it looks great  and classy but its empty. There is a market also empty. A  bus station, guess what, that's right, its empty. There are some characters who just stand there and when you try to interact they just say \"hello\" or \"don't mind me\" but they just make me hate the game even more. The good thing in this game as I have said is really the graphics. It is well done and you'll find the environment design amazing until you realize that the world is empty and it becomes dull. The sound is fine, I guess, but it still gives no life in the game. Imagine you're in all alone and you here the clarinet music in the detective movies. Wouldn't you feel so lonely? So I wouldn't really recommend the  game. I spent nearly 3 hours in the game and maybe I only enjoyed the first 5 minutes. 1.5/5, sorry. You can check more reviews from me here:", "appid": "416200", "steamid": "profiles/76561198125118164", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "10", "votes_funny": "1", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1485259200.0}

{"text": "So I picked this game up today with a coupon Steam had given me from crafting a badge, so I received it for about 34 cents. I would not pay more than the one dollar price for this game because of how badly it was developed. 1.) For starters, the keyboard controls are delayed. I press a key to move and the ball takes a second to roll, which makes it hard to stop because when you move at a fast momentum, you can't instantly start slowing down. However, this issue is gone when using a controller. 2.) There are achievements in this game for dying so many times, which isn't hard to get because all you have to do to die is press the R key. Falling off the level does not count as dying for whatever reason, so you have to kill yourself with the press of a key. 3.) The camera angle is locked in, which is a bad choice. There are times when you have to roll the ball back towards yourself as the player and you can't tell how far to jump and it makes the perspective of the platform seem farther away than what it is. 4.) As for the good things in this game, the only props I can give it is the soundtrack, which isn't really that bad; it has some decently nice music in it. The developer really hit the nail on the head when they chose the name \"DIGITAL MISTAKE\" as their company name... I would not recommend this game to anyone unless they wanted to play something broken for the laughs, which a lot of my friends do. {"text": "I like some metroidvania games (Ori and the Blind Forest and SteamWorld Dig 2 are great), but Hollow Knight just doesn't work for me. It just not fun, rather it feels a dull grind.  Positives:  Music, vocals and sounds are great and the controls are spot-on, there is no (or very little) inertia, the jumping and movement is precise and you don't get damage from falling. Negatives:  Visually it starts quite atmospheric with muted blue colours but it seems that this melancholic dullness doesn't give way to more vibrant colours (maybe in later stages?), the green colour in Greenpath area is just a variation of the same murkiness and it just gets monotonous and boring. Mapping is not available from the beginning, instead you have to kill a bunch of enemies to get in-game currency to buy an area map from the cartographer (in each area you need to find him to buy that area's map) and then you have to kill a bunch of enemies to get money to be able to buy an ability to update the map yourself (which you can only update on save benches) and if you want the map to show hot springs (healing), stag stations (fast travel) and so on, you need to grind for more currency to buy each ability separately. It doesn't take that long to get your maps to show all the essentials, but it's an unnecessary chore. There is no difficulty selection (that's a BIG negative) and after grinding past the False Knight and Hornet, I didn't care to continue playing Hollow Knight. My idea of fun isn't to battle the boss for 10+ times, each time I die, walking and jumping from the save bench to the boss through a couple of platforms and hallways. Save benches are fairly close by to the bosses (well, the first two anyway) but a 30 second jaunt to get back to the boss battle is as stupid as an unskippable animation before a bossfight. I hope the developer considers adding an easier mode, otherwise I can't recommend the game unless you like difficult games or the colour palette is to your liking.", "appid": "367520", "steamid": "profiles/76561197972581862", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "6", "votes_funny": "2", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1514289600.0}

{"text": "This review was written based off gameplay in patch 0.4.2 Astral Terra is a game that is very much in its infancy. It's probably too early for it to be sold to the public at the minute. I understand that Early Access is for games that are still developing, but I don't feel that this game is ready to demand a price tag at the moment. There's potential here, but a lot of optimisation and work needs to be done. There's a complete lack of tutorial. The game throws you in and expects you to know what you're doing. There is no way to change the key bindings at the moment. Once you have figured things out, everything in the game is a little awkward and clunky. The cursor needs to be placed exactly where the game wants it to be for something to work. This is especially frustrating when it comes to gathering materials and trying to pick them up. Everything must be clicked on individually, and sometimes you need to click outside of the texture of an item to pick it up. It leads to a lot of frustration and makes everything feel very slow and laboured. Even when terraforming, it can be difficult to get the game to do what you want it to do.  The world looks really good for a game in this genre. The environment is vibrant and huge. However, the character models are of considerably lower quality than the rest of the game, they don't fit in. Movement also looks a little unnatural.  Right now the game is essentially a creative environment and nothing more. There's no challenging enemies, just an empty world to explore. It would be acceptable for this to be a creative game if it wasn't so frustrating to play. When it feels like you're fighting the game just to be able to play it, it gets exhausting quickly. Astral Terra is not a bad game, it's just a frustrating experience right now. As the game evolves and is updated, hopefully it will become more intuitive to play and create a better experience for the user. I'll re-visit the game across it's life, and hopefully the potential will be achieved and I can change this review and recommend it. Right now, I can't justify telling anyone they should spend their money on it though.", "appid": "266190", "steamid": "profiles/76561197994239917", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "12", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": true, "tstamp_created": 1463486400.0}

{"text": "Admittedly, I got into the   series with the latest titles, namely   and the remake of  . I thoroughly enjoyed both titles, and as I do not mind playing older games, I was naturally interested in the rest of the series. So, the acclaimed fourth game was supposed to be the right choice for me. Unfortunately, I was wrong. While I cannot deny   influence on its genre, it would be a blatant lie to claim that I enjoyed playing it. The U.S. Presidentâ€™s daughter,  , was kidnapped by a mysterious Spanish cult, so the government decided to send their agent, whom players of the series already know well,  . He ventures into Spain and begins with the search in an old, abandoned village. At least it looked like it at first glance. Leon quickly finds himself surrounded by a group of hostile villagers, who seem to be under the cultâ€™s control. However, as the clocks are ticking,   has to find and save   before something happens to her and destroy the cult, if possible. Unfortunately, the whole story is just a mess full of cheesy lines and unhumorous jokes about everything by  . It becomes tiresome pretty quickly, as they are overused. Another issue is that the plot gets prolonged numerously by the constant kidnapping of  . To be honest, I expected the same or at least a similar theme as the remake of   had. Meaning, a decent horror with a few cheesy and ridiculous situations at best. Instead, I got a tedious, uninteresting plot with over usage of unfunny jokes, without any proper horror elements at all. And if this story intends to be a parody of the horror genre, then it fails tremendously. Something that annoys me right from the start is when the game locks harder difficulty setting and requires you to finish it on the lower ones first, which is even worse when it is already utterly easy to play. Nevertheless, the campaign took me around fourteen hours to finish, and I spent a few more hours with the gameâ€™s additional content. To my unpleasant surprise,   is a more linear experience than the abovementioned titles, as there is not much to explore. Most of the items, such as ammo or healing materials, are handed to you way too often, which takes away the fear of having scarce resources, making the game easier than necessary. Another issue is that puzzles are primitive, mostly requiring you to move an item from place A into place B. The only thing I liked about this simplistic exploration is that collectables are useful, as you can sell them for money at the trader. Speaking of trader, you buy weapons and upgrades from him. There is not a storage box anymore, so you have to either sell or discard superfluous items, as your inventory is limited. I am not a fan of this because it restricts me a bit, as I cannot change weapons that often anymore, which is more annoying as they are upgradable. It is also a shame because there is a decent weapon variety, as there are several types of handguns, shotguns, rifles, and such. So, some weapons might be more precise, while others offer a decent penetration through enemies. There are also grenades, which are quite fun to use. What I grew to like was the gameplay implementation of your companion,  . She has her own health bar, so you have to protect her. It adds a bit more challenge to it, as she is basically defenseless. She also occasionally points out some loot. So, overall, I prefer this approach, as it is more immersive rather than having a companion invisible to enemies. The problem with her is that her English voice is absolutely annoying, and I can hear her in my head even now. As for the enemies, they are pretty varied. Especially boss fights are interesting, as each requires a bit different strategy. There are also a few unique enemies that occasionally make combat with the hoards of regular enemies more interesting. Most of the common enemies, like villagers, can wield weapons, such as axes, crossbows, shields, and others. And you can actually shoot weapons out of their hands or even immobilize them by shooting them in the legs! Gameplay details like these are something I definitely appreciate. My main problem with the combat is that there are way too many regular enemies, like villagers. It is boring to fight them, as there is no challenge in it, and those fights are not memorable. What I enjoyed about the abovementioned   titles was that most of the encounters were a bit unique and presented a bit of challenge due to having scarce resources. You just brainlessly shoot dozens of enemies, move onto the next location, and do it again, without caring about the resources, as you know that you will get tons of them. That is just the exact opposite of the other titles, as this is rather an action game than survival horror. Regular enemies you fight most of the time also tend to sprint towards you once they spot you, but they will stop running like two meters in front of you, as they will start walking super slowly. This design decision throws any tension out of the window because you know that you will always be safe and have a lot of time to kill them. I am also not a fan of these horrible controls. I ended up using a controller, which still was not the best option, but at least it was manageable. I do not remember another shooter, made by a bigger studio, in which I would have so many problems with controlling the character. During the whole game, I had the feeling that I fight with the gameâ€™s controls than with the enemies.  , unfortunately, did not help me. New game modes unlock after finishing the campaign. The most interesting one is  , where you witness   actions during the campaign. You should play this one if you enjoyed the base game, as it expands upon its story a bit. It took me around three hours to finish it. Another one,   is rather a minigame, where you collect some samples, and I would not bother with it. The last one,  , is about killing waves of enemies. It is intended for people who enjoy the gameâ€™s combat, so I did not bother replaying it. Nevertheless, it is a nice addition. Although visuals are pretty dated, I still love the gameâ€™s distinctive locations. You will visit a foggy village, castle, caves, labs, and more. It manages to provide a decent variety to keep you interested. I especially liked the castle chapters due to its design. The appearance of various monsters should receive a fair share of praise too. Unfortunately, I cannot say the same about the soundtrack, as it is pretty forgettable, and some of the English voice actors deliver a questionable quality. The game was tested with an  , running at the highest settings, at  , at  . However, if the framerate does not run constantly on 30 or 60 frames, the game tends to run in some weird slow-motion mode. Sweet gameplay details, weapons and locationâ€™s variety, as well as good-looking monsters cannot save this game for me. Mediocre port, terrible controls, uninteresting story, no horror elements at all, and tiresome combat is all I have in mind when thinking about this game. Maybe the possible upcoming remake will make it better?", "appid": "254700", "steamid": "profiles/76561198111956371", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "21", "votes_funny": "6", "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1604059200.0}

{"text": "Pure, unadulterated rubbish. Ahem. Deep breath, step back. I play a lot of games. Most fade into the realm of decent to mediocre. Once in a while, something breaks into the extreme end. A beautiful, inspiring experience, perhaps, or something so bewilderingly bad as to sear itself into my memory. This is in the latter category. It opens with interminable cutscenes amid a tutorial. Other reviewers have remarked on that point, so I was forewarned. I was willing to bear through it in hope that, once past that hump, the game would improve. Perhaps, I thought, they were too quick to judge. That hope was misplaced.  Let's return to the cutscenes. Toe-curlingly, embarrassingly, painfully bad. It's not just the opening, but persistent through the six hours I managed to stomach before giving up. Bizarre caricatures spouting nonsense which just goes on and on. Frye's introduction in particular was just so jaw-droppingly stupid that I half expected that the game was an elaborate hidden-camera show and the devs were going to pop out of my wardrobe laughing any moment. The art is, frankly, ugly. If the scenes weren't long enough as it was, I'd be tempted to rewind just to see what the hell some frames were meant to be. Then there's gameplay which can be broken into two aspects, dispatch and tactical.  The dispatch stuff could have been interesting - I loved Emergency back in the day, and 911 Operator is great. However, it's mostly shallow choose-your-own-adventure stuff, with so much nonsense from your crew (won't work with women, won't work with lower-rated partners, drunk, etc) that it's more annoying than interesting. Sidenote - what tone is this game going for? It seems to bounce all over the place. Tactical is even worse. It's done far better in other games, from XCOM to Phantom Doctrine and many others. It's clumsy, slow, often unfair (with potentially big consequences for failure) and the tutorial does stuff-all explaining it.  Oh, and there are fail states which just pop up willy-nilly - as if the game wasn't bad enough, get ready to replay chunks of it. {"text": "Don't play this â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, lot of bug and lag..", "appid": "1255060", "steamid": "profiles/76561198042308168", "voted_up": false, "votes_up": "2", "votes_funny": 0, "early_access": false, "tstamp_created": 1605268800.0}
{"text": "Dog Duty is an isometric real-time tactics game where the player must defeat three bosses to get to the final showdown. Unfortunately, the game is very short, with each boss only taking an hour to complete. The gameplay is sadly not good enough to make a game this short worth the $15 price tag.   The overworld is comprised of a small hub world that has three paths to three different islands which have a theme, though there is a lot of environmental overlap and the environment only changes gameplay in the swamp. In the swamp, there are areas that are filled with water that slow characters down which makes them easy targets. The overworld is pretty large, which is why the playerâ€™s mercenaries stand atop three different vehicle types which all drive almost exactly the same way, with the player clicking and holding in one place and the vehicle will drive towards the mouse cursor. One quality of life feature I would have liked to see would have been a minimap while driving. Due to the lack of a minimap, I found myself opening the full map a frustrating amount of times. Combat is the focus of this game, though it is a bit simplistic and not in a refined way. Each of the three mercenaries has a weapon that can be changed. They will automatically fire at any enemies within their range when they arenâ€™t moving. It is for this reason that the stealth mechanics donâ€™t really work. Enemies will notice player movement from a distance and they will investigate allowing for the player to bait enemies into ambushes, but it also would be great to get around enemies consider the lack of cover at the beginning of a lot of stages. The aforementioned mechanic where allies shoot immediately and automatically will cause enemies to go straight into combat instead of staying in the stealth mode. Once combat is initiated it becomes a clunky and boring ordeal. Besides automatically attacking, the player is able to use a few items such as molotovs, which helps to clear an area, though I didnâ€™t find them very necessary. Each mercenary also has a special ability that is unlimited with a cooldown. The issue with this is that some mercenaries have abilities that are much better than the others. I never removed the healing character because he made the game more enjoyable as I was able to save my mercenaries that were grouped together. This wouldnâ€™t be quite as necessary if there was more cover. By standing behind a wall of sandbags, damage to mercenaries and enemies behind this wall will be greatly reduced. Cover is so sparse for the player that I ended up forgetting about it most of the time. If a mercenaries health is reduced to nothing they get downed and can be picked up by an ally. There isnâ€™t much of a penalty for this which surprised me as it is usually a big deal in this kind of game.  While driving vehicles there will occasionally be an opportunity to fight a vehicle battle. Vehicle battles are not very fun as they require a ton of micomanagement and there isnâ€™t any cover on vehicles, even with the two objects every vehicle can have on top of it. Missiles slowly rain down from above which will deal fifty percent of any mercenaryâ€™s health instantly. There are other vehicles that will throw a time bomb that a single mercenary has to focus on disarming. Combine these two tasks with fighting without any cover against tanky enemies and one gets a less than fun mechanic that is thankfully optional unless the player wants the money, which is ultimately useless.  There are a few different weapons to choose from, but I found that the sniper rifle is the most over powered of all of them. This is because it has surprisingly high attack speed while dealing a lot of damage and going through enemy cover completely. The consumable arenâ€™t especially interesting and I repeatedly spent my money on Molotov Cocktails as they were near instant death against a group of enemies.  Enemies are recycled throughout the three islands. There is the grunt, the sniper, a tanky guy, and a commander. Sometimes they have a different weapon in their hands, though they donâ€™t require any new tactics. Each of the levels, besides the boss battle one, will disable one particular part of the enemyâ€™s operations on that particular island. A few examples would be that the player can raid the enemyâ€™s armory to steal the armor and if the entire stage is cleared out then enemies lose their armor. I never felt the effects of this mechanic though as enemies always felt the same way. I even tried going straight to the boss level for the final level and it didnâ€™t feel any more difficult. Bosses are a slog as all of them boil down to hiding behind the obvious piece of cover and then running out to attack the boss again. The story is fun, the little bit of it that there is. There is a bit initially which is fun and parodies the story of a lot of action movies. There is then a huge story drought with minor story events only occurring whenever there is a boss fight. The sound design is annoying due to the low amount of sound variety. The minigun weapon plays the same sound every time it shoots a bullet and enemies that see the player will often yell the same line causing a cacophony of layered sounds. One of the biggest offenders would be that the playerâ€™s mercenaries would sometimes play voice clips very loudly even though I had my sound down to twenty-five percent. This happened more than once and it hurt quite a bit. The graphics are quite nice. The are a lower polygon style that reminds me of the original quake but with textures that help to give the game a bit of a pixel art look. There are a few graphical glitches such logs hit in the swamp changing lighting all of a sudden. There also isnâ€™t much in the way of enemy graphical differences between the three island zones. The swamp zone is original, but the other two zones are recycled desert graphics. The first issue I had with the controls would be that the select box bugs out a lot and gets stuck in box select mode which makes it impossible to maneuver all of the units quickly. It is also really hard to tell if a character is selected or night as the rings around them donâ€™t change color or indicate it in any meaningful way.  :  I had two crashes during my time playing for no apparent reason.
